{"Status": "Page", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "A Hubble Space Telescope lensing survey of X-ray luminous galaxy clusters - IV. Mass, structure and thermodynamics of cluster cores at z= 0.2", "authors": ["Smith, Graham P.", "Kneib, Jean-Paul", "Smail, Ian", "Mazzotta, Pasquale", "Ebeling, Harald", "Czoske, Oliver"], "author_address": ["AA(California Institute of Technology, Mail Code 105-24, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA ; Department of Physics, University of Durham, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE), AB(California Institute of Technology, Mail Code 105-24, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA; Observatoire Midi-Pyr\u00e9n\u00e9es, 14 Avenue E. Belin, 31400 Toulouse, France), AC(Institute for Computational Cosmology, University of Durham, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE), AD(Institute for Computational Cosmology, University of Durham, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE; Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA), AE(Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, USA), AF(Observatoire Midi-Pyr\u00e9n\u00e9es, 14 Avenue E. Belin, 31400 Toulouse, France; Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik und Extraterrestrische Forschung, Universit\u00e4t Bonn, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 71, 53121 Bonn, Germany)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "359", "publication_year": "2005/05/1", "start_page": "417", "end_page": "446", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing", "galaxies: clusters: general", "cosmology: observations", "dark matter", "large scale structure of Universe", "X-rays: galaxies: clusters", "Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005MNRAS.359..417S", "abstract": "We present a comprehensive space-based study of 10 X-ray luminous galaxy clusters (L<SUB>X</SUB>>= 8 \u00d7 10<SUP>44</SUP> erg s<SUP>-1</SUP>, 0.1-2.4 keV) at z= 0.2. Hubble Space Telescope (HST) observations reveal numerous gravitationally lensed arcs for which we present four new spectroscopic redshifts, bringing the total to 13 confirmed arcs in this cluster sample. The confirmed arcs reside in just half of the clusters; we thus obtain a firm lower limit on the fraction of clusters with a central projected mass density exceeding the critical density required for strong lensing of 50 per cent. We combine the multiple-image systems with the weakly sheared background galaxies to model the total mass distribution in the cluster cores (R<= 500 kpc). These models are complemented by high-resolution X-ray data from Chandra and used to develop quantitative criteria to classify the clusters as relaxed or unrelaxed. Formally, (30 +/- 20) per cent of the clusters form a relatively homogeneous subsample of relaxed clusters; the remaining (70 +/- 20) per cent are unrelaxed and are a much more diverse population. Most of the clusters therefore appear to be experiencing a cluster-cluster merger or relaxing after such an event. We also study the normalization and scatter of scaling relations between the cluster mass, the X-ray luminosity and the temperature. The scatter in these relations is dominated by the unrelaxed clusters and is typically \u03c3~= 0.4. Most notably, we detect two to three times more scatter in the mass-temperature relation than theoretical simulations and models predict. The observed scatter is also asymmetric - the unrelaxed clusters are systematically 40 per cent hotter than the relaxed clusters at 2.5\u03c3 significance. This structural segregation should be a major concern for experiments designed to constrain cosmological parameters using galaxy clusters. Overall our results are consistent with a scenario of cluster-cluster merger-induced boosts to cluster X-ray luminosities and temperatures.", "doi": "10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:astro-ph/0403588", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005MNRAS.359..417S", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2005MNRAS.359..417S/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Loaded page", "Paper text": "\r\n\r\n\r\n<!DOCTYPE html>\r\n<html lang=\"en\" class=\"no-js\">\r\n\r\n<head>\r\n\r\n        <title>Hubble Space Telescope lensing survey of X-ray luminous galaxy clusters \u2013 IV. $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin js-nav-dropdown js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f359%2f2%2f417%2f986735\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\"                                  <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term at-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225270 id=\"17225270\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a comprehensive space-based study of 10 X-ray luminous galaxy clusters (<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 0.1\u20132.4 keV) at <em>z</em> = 0.2. <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) observations reveal numerous gravitationally lensed arcs for which we present four new spectroscopic redshifts, bringing the total to 13 confirmed arcs in this cluster sample. The confirmed arcs reside in just half of the clusters; we thus obtain a firm lower limit on the fraction of clusters with a central projected mass density exceeding the critical density required for strong lensing of 50 per cent. We combine the multiple-image systems with the weakly sheared background galaxies to model the total mass distribution in the cluster cores (<em>R</em> \u2264 500 kpc). These models are complemented by high-resolution X-ray data from <em>Chandra</em> and used to develop quantitative criteria to classify the clusters as relaxed or unrelaxed. Formally, (30 \u00b1 20) per cent of the clusters form a relatively homogeneous subsample of relaxed clusters; the remaining (70 \u00b1 20) per cent are unrelaxed and are a much more diverse population. Most of the clusters therefore appear to be experiencing a cluster\u2013cluster merger or relaxing after such an event. We also study the normalization and scatter of scaling relations between the cluster mass, the X-ray luminosity and the temperature. The scatter in these relations is dominated by the unrelaxed clusters and is typically \u03c3 \u2243 0.4. Most notably, we detect two to three times more scatter in the mass\u2013temperature relation than theoretical simulations and models predict. The observed scatter is also asymmetric \u2013 the unrelaxed clusters are systematically 40 per cent hotter than the relaxed clusters at 2.5\u03c3 significance. This structural segregation should be a major concern for experiments designed to constrain cosmological parameters using galaxy clusters. Overall our results are consistent with a scenario of cluster\u2013cluster merger-induced boosts to cluster X-ray luminosities and temperatures.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing&quot;\">gravitational lensing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmology: observations&quot;\">cosmology: observations</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;large scale structure of Universe&quot;\">large scale structure of Universe</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;X-rays: galaxies: clusters&quot;\">X-rays: galaxies: clusters</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225272 id=\"17225272\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 Introduction</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Massive galaxy clusters are the largest collapsed structures in the Universe (<em>M</em><sub>virial</sub>\u2243 10<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>), containing vast quantities of the putative dark matter (DM), hot intracluster gas (<em>kT</em><sub>X</sub>\u2243 7 keV) and galaxies (<em>n</em><sub>gal</sub>\u223c 10<sup>3</sup>). These rare systems stand at the nodes of the \u2018cosmic web\u2019 as defined by the large-scale filaments seen in both galaxy redshift surveys (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">De Lapparent, Geller &amp; Huchra 1986</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Shectman et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vettolani et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Peacock et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zehavi et al. 2002</a>) and numerical simulations of structure formation (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bond, Kofman &amp; Pogosyan 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Yoshida et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evrard et al. 2002</a>). Clusters are inferred to assemble by accreting matter along the filamentary axes, slowly (<em>t</em><sub>crossing</sub>\u223c 2\u20133 Gyr) ingesting DM, gas and stars into their deep gravitational potential wells.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters have long been recognized as cosmological probes. For example, the evolution of cluster substructure with look-back time is, in principle, a powerful diagnostic of the cosmological parameters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gunn &amp; Gott 1972</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Peebles 1980</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richstone, Loeb &amp; Turner 1992</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evrard et al. 1993</a>). A complementary probe is to constrain the matter density of the Universe and the normalization of the matter power spectrum using the cluster mass function. However, it is currently not possible to measure the cluster mass function directly. More easily accessible surrogates such as the X-ray luminosity and temperature functions are therefore used in combination with scaling relations between the relevant quantities (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Eke, Cole &amp; Frenk 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Reiprich &amp; B\u00f6hringer 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Viana, Nichol &amp; Liddle 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2003</a>). A critical component of such analyses is the precision to which the scaling relations are known. Samples of X-ray-selected clusters are now of a sufficient size that systematic uncertainties may be comparable to the statistical uncertainties, and therefore deserve careful analysis before robust cosmological conclusions may be drawn (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2003</a>). Measurements of the Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich effect (SZE) are also emerging as a powerful cosmological tool (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Carlstrom et al. 2002</a> for a recent review). Cosmological SZE surveys will rely on the cluster mass\u2013temperature relationship in a similar manner to cosmological X-ray surveys. Such experiments may therefore also be compromised if astrophysical systematic effects are not identified and carefully eliminated from the analysis (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Majumdar &amp; Mohr 2003</a>). A detailed study of the assembly and relaxation histories of clusters, and their global scaling relations as a function of redshift is therefore vitally important.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To advance our understanding of the assembly, relaxation and thermodynamics of massive galaxy clusters requires information concerning the spatial distribution of DM, hot gas and galaxies in clusters. Several baryonic mass tracers are available, for example X-ray emission from the intracluster medium (hereafter ICM, e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jones &amp; Forman 1984</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Buote &amp; Tsai 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schuecker et al. 2001</a>) and the angular and line-of-sight velocity distribution of cluster galaxies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Geller &amp; Beers 1982</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dressler &amp; Shectman 1988</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">West &amp; Bothun 1990</a>). These diagnostics have often been used as surrogates for a direct tracer of the underlying DM distribution. The major drawback of this approach is the requirement to assume a relationship between the luminous and dark matter distributions (e.g. that the ICM is in hydrostatic equilibrium with the DM potential) \u2013 it is precisely these assumptions that require detailed testing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing offers a solution to much of this problem, in that the lensing signal is sensitive to the total mass distribution in the lens, regardless of its physical nature and state. A detailed study of gravitational lensing by massive clusters is therefore an important opportunity to gain an empirical understanding of the distribution of DM in clusters. Early comparisons between X-ray and lensing-based mass measurements revealed a factor of 2\u20133 discrepancy between the two techniques (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miralda-Escud\u00e9 &amp; Babul 1995</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wu &amp; Fang 1997</a>), although the agreement between weak-lensing and X-ray measurements was generally better, albeit within large uncertainties (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Squires et al. 1996, 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1997</a>). The simplifying assumptions involved in the X-ray analysis were soon identified as the likely dominant source of this discrepancy; this was confirmed by several authors (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wu et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wu 2000</a>). In summary, X-ray and lensing mass measurements for the most relaxed clusters agree well if the multiphase nature of the ICM in cool cores (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen, Schmidt &amp; Fabian 2001</a>) is incorporated into the X-ray analysis. The situation is more complex in more dynamically disturbed clusters, with larger discrepancies being found at smaller projected radii.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An important caveat to adopting lensing as the tool of choice for measuring cluster mass is that lensing actually constrains the projected mass distribution along the line of sight to the cluster. The addition of three-dimensional information into lensing studies may therefore be important before final conclusions are drawn. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Czoske et al.'s</a> (2001; 2002; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2003</a>) wide-field redshift survey of Cl 0024+1654 at <em>z</em> = 0.395 revealed that this strong-lensing cluster (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>) is not relaxed as had been previously assumed (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson, Kochanski &amp; dell'Antonio 1998</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Early gravitational lensing studies of galaxy clusters concentrated on individual clusters selected because of their prominent arcs (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mellier, Fort &amp; Kneib 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1994, 1995, 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1995a, 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen, Fabian &amp; Kneib 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson et al. 1998</a>). This \u2018prominent arc\u2019 selection function was vital to developing the techniques required to interpret the gravitational lensing signal (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser &amp; Squires 1993</a>). However, this selection function also made it difficult to draw conclusions concerning galaxy clusters as a population from these studies. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1997)</a> made early progress toward studying lensing in large samples of clusters, using the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) to study 12 optically rich clusters. As X-ray-selected samples became available, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Luppino et al. (1999)</a> also searched for gravitational arcs in ground-based imaging of 38 X-ray luminous clusters. The broad conclusions to emerge from these pioneering studies were that to use gravitational lensing to learn about clusters as a population, a selection function that mimics mass selection as closely as possible and the superb angular resolution available from <em>HST</em> imaging are both key requirements.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We are conducting an <em>HST</em> survey of an objectively selected sample of 10 X-ray luminous (and thus massive) clusters at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>). Previous papers in this series have presented: (i) a detailed analysis of the density profile of A 383 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2001</a>); (ii) a search for gravitationally lensed extremely red objects (EROs, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2002a</a>); and (iii) near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy of ERO J003707, a multiply imaged ERO at <em>z</em> = 1.6 behind the foreground cluster A 68 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2002b</a>). This paper describes the gravitational lensing analysis of all 10 clusters observed with <em>HST</em> and uses the resulting models of the cluster cores to measure the mass and structure of the clusters on scales of <em>R</em> \u2264 500 kpc. We also exploit archival <em>Chandra</em> observations and NIR photometry of likely cluster galaxies to compare the distribution of total mass in the clusters with the gaseous and stellar components, respectively. This combination of strong-lensing, X-ray and NIR diagnostics enable us to quantify the prevalence of dynamical immaturity in the X-ray luminous population at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 and to calibrate the high-mass end of the cluster mass\u2013temperature relationship.</p>                        <a id=\"17225280\" scrollto-destination=\"17225280\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=0wWxqs0i0rd7dnAkFYCMMxC-5mUZVLPTvyJALW24yrJgTNzexyaxWn29INSTlNaiIYA50miIU8nPtagH5erutDaxgY2TiNdnWNfgNZolWRp4ALx91qV18ywGZ0jwwCnDVBZaUu9SOHF~5BVzepa0mZUPU~oHg1zdk1dobPJN~zQlT0B2ITDI~Gcw3QIpQW6yFj1PHPcgkWcyoxL~F-BOhfAX~CA4An0lyLbmwsLkJCS3NuoT3bWGFGiQ~X29NH4objbyapfv0K2qfZ~NRx4wupPJaSCoSCRMeia4cOS90v7GmR96WNaEz3D6BFWEVXlunyk-Tci2~FzBsFniR8DfUw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> observations.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=0wWxqs0i0rd7dnAkFYCMMxC-5mUZVLPTvyJALW24yrJgTNzexyaxWn29INSTlNaiIYA50miIU8nPtagH5erutDaxgY2TiNdnWNfgNZolWRp4ALx91qV18ywGZ0jwwCnDVBZaUu9SOHF~5BVzepa0mZUPU~oHg1zdk1dobPJN~zQlT0B2ITDI~Gcw3QIpQW6yFj1PHPcgkWcyoxL~F-BOhfAX~CA4An0lyLbmwsLkJCS3NuoT3bWGFGiQ~X29NH4objbyapfv0K2qfZ~NRx4wupPJaSCoSCRMeia4cOS90v7GmR96WNaEz3D6BFWEVXlunyk-Tci2~FzBsFniR8DfUw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of Hubble Space Telescope observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225280/359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225280\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=i5Y0njM5eu0WFchZY~rMC-ZDZDVDX-uNcXFMEybv95v~ojHlH7aO-kerKeQ7QeYoDONu1QrprtNOFNoe9qMIBuGeladMgoFJCPIMsAOBKj~k2HkW6UpMzxtjHIOPm~me8BUxIx3gR7T7zghfoN0zpMCFRKCzCcD8TT3fqPxTFIBoJPSL7FrGIow-zIr6iHYiBGEty1Cm~Wc1I3kxOZHKxw10kS89gGGxx-O3m580-2GObGner~iXcTAGb3xmIiiS4XmEABsoArP65D81Ze~EFcfwi5eTHzsH3oPfmZRX59oPe1tyBI18TM5jh3GD-7hNg6hC4bDKsbRgSXaXVmZ2pw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225280&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl001.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> observations.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We outline the organization of the paper. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a> we describe the survey design and sample selection. We then explain the reduction and analysis of the optical data in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>, comprising the <em>HST</em> imaging data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.1</a>) and new spectroscopic redshift measurements for arcs in A 68 and A 2219 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>). The end-point of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a> is a definition of the strong- and weak-lensing constraints available for all 10 clusters. We use these constraints in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a> to construct detailed gravitational lens models of the cluster potential wells; the details of the modelling techniques are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix A</a>, and the process of fitting the constraints in each cluster are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>. We then complement these gravitational lensing results with observations of the X-ray emission from the ICM of the clusters, drawn from the <em>Chandra</em> data archive (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>). The main results of the paper are then presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6</a>, including measurements of the mass and maturity of the clusters and a detailed study of the cluster scaling relations. We discuss the interpretation of the results in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7\"></span><a href=\"#ss7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 7</a> and briefly assess their impact on attempts to use clusters as cosmological probes. Finally, we summarize our conclusions in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss8\"></span><a href=\"#ss8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 8</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assume a spatially flat universe with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 50 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>q</em><sub>0</sub> = 0.5; in this cosmology 1 arcsec \u2261 4.2 kpc at <em>z</em> = 0.2. Our main results are insensitive to this choice of cosmology, for example, the cluster mass measurements would be modified by \u226410 per cent if we adopted the currently favoured values of \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 65 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. We also adopt the complex deformation, <strong>\u03c4</strong> =\u03c4<sub><em>x</em></sub>+ i\u03c4<sub><em>y</em></sub> = |<strong>\u03c4</strong>| e<sup>2i\u03b8</sup>, as our measure of galaxy shape when dealing with the weak-lensing aspects of our analysis, where \u03c4= (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>+<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/2<em>ab</em> and \u03b8 is the position angle of the major axis of the ellipse that describes each galaxy. We define the terms \u2018ellipticity\u2019 to mean \u03c4 and \u2018orientation\u2019 to mean \u03b8. All uncertainties are quoted at the 68 per cent confidence level.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225283 id=\"17225283\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 Sample Selection</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We aim to study massive galaxy clusters, and so would prefer to select clusters based on their mass. Mass-selected cluster catalogues extracted from ground-based observations are gradually becoming available (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wittman et al. 2003</a>), however, the blurring effect of the atmosphere makes the completeness of these weak-lensing cluster catalogues very difficult to characterize robustly. These surveys are also unlikely to achieve the sky coverage (of the order of full sky) required to detect a large sample of the rarest and most massive systems which are the focus of our programme. In contrast, X-ray-selected cluster catalogues (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gioia et al. 1990</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">De Grandi et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry 2000</a>) based on the <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey are already available in the public domain with well-defined completeness limits. X-ray selection also influences the choice of survey epoch because the completeness of the X-ray cluster catalogues at the time that we applied for <em>HST</em> time in cycle 8 (GO-8249) falls off rapidly beyond <em>z</em>\u2243 0.3. We therefore adopt <em>z</em> = 0.2 as the nominal redshift of our cluster sample. This redshift is also well suited to a lensing survey because the observer\u2013lens, observer\u2013source and lens\u2013source angular diameter distances (<em>D</em><sub>OL</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>OS</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>LS</sub>) that control the power and efficiency of gravitational lenses render clusters at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 powerful lenses for background galaxy populations at <em>z</em>\u223c 0.7\u20131.5. This redshift interval is well matched to the current generation of optical spectrographs on 10-m class telescopes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Accordingly, we selected 10 of the most X-ray luminous clusters (<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 0.1\u20132.4 keV) in a narrow redshift slice at 0.17 \u2264<em>z</em> \u2264 0.25, with minimal line-of-sight reddening [<em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u2212<em>V</em>) \u2264 0.1] from the X-ray brightest Abell-type clusters (XBACs; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 1996</a>) sample. These clusters span the full range of X-ray properties (morphology, central galaxy line emission, cooling flow rate and core radius) found in larger X-ray luminous samples (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Peres et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Crawford et al. 1999</a>). The median X-ray luminosity of the sample is 13 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We list the cluster sample in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. As XBACs is restricted to Abell clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Abell, Corwin &amp; Olowin 1989</a>), the sample is not strictly X-ray-selected. However, a comparison with the X-ray-selected <em>ROSAT</em> Brightest Cluster Sample (BCS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 1998, 2000</a>) shows that 18 of the 19 BCS clusters that satisfy our selection criteria are either Abell or Zwicky clusters. This confirms that our sample is indistinguishable from a genuinely X-ray-selected sample.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225286 id=\"17225286\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 Optical Data and Analysis</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225287 id=\"17225287\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1 <em>HST</em> observations and data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All 10 clusters were observed through the F702W filter using the WFPC2 camera on-board <em>HST</em>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><!----></a> The total exposure time for each cluster is listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. We adopted a three-point dither pattern for the eight clusters (A 68, A 209, A 267, A 383, A 773, A 963, A 1763, A 1835) observed in cycle 8: each exposure was shifted relative to the previous exposure by 10 WFC pixels (\u223c1.0 arcsec) in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em>. The archival observations of A 2218 follow the same dither pattern, except the offsets were three WFC pixels in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em>. A 2219 was observed with a six-point dither pattern that comprised two three-point dithers each of which were identical to that used for the cycle 8 observations. These two dither patterns were offset from each other by 10 pixels in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure the actual dither pattern and compare it with the commanded integer pixel offsets; the median difference between the commanded and actual offsets is 0.2 pixels, and generally lies in the range \u223c 0 to 0.4 pixels. The geometrical distortion at the edge of each chip (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gilmozzi, Ewald &amp; Kinney 1995</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Holtzman et al. 1995</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Trauger et al. 1995</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Casertano &amp; Wiggs 2001</a>) translates to an additional \u223c0.2 pixel shift at the edge of each detector, falling to zero at the chip centres. Our observations therefore subsample the 0.1-arcsec WFC pixels at a level that varies spatially in the range \u223c0 to 0.5 pixels. We therefore use the <span class=\"small-caps\">dither</span> package (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fruchter &amp; Hook 1997</a>) to reduce the <em>HST</em> data because this allows us to correct for the geometrical distortion and to recover a limited amount of spatial information from the undersampled WFPC2 point spread function (PSF). The final reduced frames (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>) have a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec and an effective resolution of FWHM = 0.17 arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"17225290\" scrollto-destination=\"17225290\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig001.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=glKnMRLt~Y989WPQZRWA2Yzfd1LCxcWJfI9XCCYYcV-2~rZbzc7C079i3DLdH7eAXubPNwOc1shzmJ1Ha0RQf8ARJEx9ZvUwIA3wC1UUonm8En57czwZtqCfzl4BPTlXml5bdeOOsFBuc5U4mHJTGH7cDttJafiY4pG6piRpV7e-OGZ4Vo5VsGGeIjoyBNAQWsv39n~GgibBYB-bXu2it~kbJKCch-I4~XB~FddFBZMS68OxHoRlV5aIruAgA3mVtKUZzUNvw5KOmB~mQxPTccQuAUSt1LtYZZbuGdj9eQPZGrJuQ6aIegPLw62Xtc79VQrOwfRc69fkrR09KmAuxg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The HST/WFPC2 frames of all 10 clusters on a logarithmic scale and a false colour table. We overplot the weak shear field; these vectors show the mean ellipticity and orientation of faint background field galaxies on a grid that has been smoothed with a Gaussian of \u03c3= 10 arcsec. The tickmarks are centred on the central galaxy (Table 1) and are separated by 10 arcsec. The centre of each major mass component included in the lens models is marked (see Table 4).\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig001.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225290/359-2-417-fig001.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig001.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225290\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig001.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=WmQ4dR~WrihwQkWAQvx7UBzLQumTh-GN5KbD1JCazYiT8GzE2j4oLczyZci-AD2BXwGMYZq-50rpiexmKD6O6RWIEPX8U3SRyRZ4GQlSZ0aAsFoDDV1sE87iu17ZAXeDk5WuYCalvoMtt3O6LHCqYYzHbo1eP0pK5~yr5Rkb7R5250jqWVjnPHrBsqzckJj4TEmyJTGSgYFyyzdtakBkW3Ynu9FtoA61O-ynvtNI8Q7vbiheA108L3g2NkyuQ2Tg5zrgIWRgaYnHsHMP71UOeyvvTah0n0LlUZcD0LGupOLVNSXuuVCwbZVzAhsmksjDVY5H6EPyNqmvzXeH2cTj9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=17225290&amp;ar=986735&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig001.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig002.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=HKElIwqYzoRhAIWIXUtgGJ7y-t1lnZJDhiTm92KO0p2JDj6udL0TjNDT5fByoKXlQEg1bJ0r37kqn3MrWFhoId85aj5gpJ03AFWoAvJwlCDw~T4~469hg1Y1Bs6j62zCrqjDPUjRY5DxKOgZtxgva1z6zlw31mclIjJ8I9LQbJLK02HJAXwAaH0T7pupJnCUdGuWcVovft6TnqiWXM~qYOz1n5sZyJVjEf7tP1xwGWN0r-XPxg9aPMdptr7Q4UA3PCkAWZg-X7RAihLMO0nW-STetYsB0dpr~8Y~H9PJixRpozXIwCfqsm6JcMbR-6wcctdsdNusj44GAML1JuhB2g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The HST/WFPC2 frames of all 10 clusters on a logarithmic scale and a false colour table. We overplot the weak shear field; these vectors show the mean ellipticity and orientation of faint background field galaxies on a grid that has been smoothed with a Gaussian of \u03c3= 10 arcsec. The tickmarks are centred on the central galaxy (Table 1) and are separated by 10 arcsec. The centre of each major mass component included in the lens models is marked (see Table 4).\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig002.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225290/359-2-417-fig002.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig002.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225290\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig002.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=gL7JVUQ0x~IDHayfc8kQu8ZAsXdK~5OH5zMDSSyi6nuk2B56vp3VapKcdXJyC3VUANFDSCHSk4RFnI1~m79Jb~0JEWYYeNFxzzIwoW-qRYBPl494EatrywRhjXz9LATMatW-Ydfchyy1xfwvXvs9bwgAox8kXUXhizOQNLBOh8j6HJ~fytpZ0aDEF30FhabdRGDKHA1H77ujg-FSW3xIdkNvatdDN7mSmM3f2H9uEg2fClAeIgNIu88ptSizt-BxHKBZh7ShYdZ7zLfvOyjN6qx9vcXmg8uZXhH0ydLLArNBlx53hMPJmbxWeQFTy4SCH~pZ0tGD5d9YOw2LY~sM3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=17225290&amp;ar=986735&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig002.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 frames of all 10 clusters on a logarithmic scale and a false colour table. We overplot the weak shear field; these vectors show the mean ellipticity and orientation of faint background field galaxies on a grid that has been smoothed with a Gaussian of \u03c3= 10 arcsec. The tickmarks are centred on the central galaxy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>) and are separated by 10 arcsec. The centre of each major mass component included in the lens models is marked (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225292 id=\"17225292\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2 Identification and confirmation of multiple-image candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The primary reason for observing the cluster cores with <em>HST</em> is to take advantage of the superb angular resolution of these data to identify multiply imaged galaxies. Spectroscopic confirmation of such systems provides a very tight constraint on the projected total (dark plus luminous) mass of each cluster on scales of several hundred kiloparsecs, and the spatial distribution of the cluster mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We therefore begin the analysis by searching the <em>HST</em> frames for candidate multiple-image systems. This search combines visual inspection of the data (looking for symmetric image pairs and tangentially or radially distorted arcs) with the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> source catalogues described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>. The effective surface brightness limit of the search in regions not affected by bright cluster galaxies is therefore \u03bc<sub>702</sub>\u2243 25 mag arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>). To overcome the influence of bright cluster members, we generated unsharp-masked versions of the science frames, thus removing most of the flux from the bright galaxies. For example, this exercise helped us to identify C19 under the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) in A 68 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>). The residual light from the bright galaxies in these unsharp-masked frames inevitably brightens the surface-brightness limit of the multiple-image search close to the cores (central few arcsec) of the subtracted galaxies. However, the only images that we expect to find in such locations are strongly de-amplified counter-images, the brighter images of which should be easily detectable elsewhere in the frame, if they lie above the surface brightness detection limit. We therefore expect the search for multiple-image systems to be reasonably complete to \u03bc<sub>702</sub>\u2243 25 mag arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>.</p>                        <a id=\"17225296\" scrollto-destination=\"17225296\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig003.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=YIRzzOUToyx3k8c3AyX6TMDvATwy43vqffxkUJir1rY~ekMSiisaKDsQNTA2iuYSiPxCYegm80JK3Qi52xPmja3ArxJSAfODA4UwriuGU8xawNbSEWIS96llSX3ISgk0AARbuEnWspqU1rePnVKPzAvlXQy88Pf~rjouNpsYsZMSt9JkxTu-JUlxKkI0kgLyLSiM2r-Te8DTyCUf1nCjd5d7xMidRPIVaS5CzTYmuFLoZQ6hw39htk3nqHeAfhlgKR-L0bgGQadyxBQY2vavGeF25WbCTq-ilGXNDLuKzH9mU9oQ26-IzI7RznZVDT1bOyzrPSaaOV0mpUG0wERNOw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Zooms into the central region of the clusters showing the confirmed and candidate multiple-image systems discussed in the text. The black curves follow the z = 1.60, 5.4, z = 1.01, z = 0.771, z = 0.702 and z = 1.069, 3.666 tangential critical curves for A 68, A 383, A 963. A 2218 and A2219, respectively, as computed from the lens models. The bar at the bottom left of each panel shows a physical scale of 50 kpc. The orientation of each panel matches the corresponding panel in Fig. 1; tick marks are spaced at 5-arcsec intervals.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig004.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225296/359-2-417-fig004.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig004.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225296\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig004.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=hOz1y3ScEM5zfvDEgKsT8qsuJm~QkOyh5KleW1UgtqwWqSewy83mts7YFlGvPiKKJ8zQgXvPy3fMU~6RPNqSprGe9Roh6s2bwOGFWugrqeZb5bffUQHVw67Iqq0iBoeIIDJWVRwAi4v6rSAfHOO1LZeAoMCqtv-7yfV7C2zSez25LI32IJCp9cx1p8cRSgkku1qBJ8LXbBA4wAg5PU9SW1mR4OrwTsRwuZYk85BoH2FHHQgKDd-48ysbroa9bQSFJFHazUCw3es1stTeBGhWEvkE0AIyT1Iz-YmIDBj43k7b-7eOjY3FF2n9IgnbhMKnIbY9kpiCev7W-sej6o3ddA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=17225296&amp;ar=986735&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig004.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Zooms into the central region of the clusters showing the confirmed and candidate multiple-image systems discussed in the text. The black curves follow the <em>z</em> = 1.60, 5.4, <em>z</em> = 1.01, <em>z</em> = 0.771, <em>z</em> = 0.702 and <em>z</em> = 1.069, 3.666 tangential critical curves for A 68, A 383, A 963. A 2218 and A2219, respectively, as computed from the lens models. The bar at the bottom left of each panel shows a physical scale of 50 kpc. The orientation of each panel matches the corresponding panel in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>; tick marks are spaced at 5-arcsec intervals.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We mark all of the multiple-image candidates in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a> and list them, together with their positions relative to the BCG in each cluster in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss13\"></span><a href=\"#ss13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix C</a>. We also list a subset of the multiple-image candidates in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>\u2013 faint sources are excluded if they are not obviously multiply imaged, based on morphological grounds, including examination of issues relating to the parity of possible counter images (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith 2002</a> for a more detailed discussion of issues relating to the identification of multiple-image candidates). The clusters are subdivided in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> into those with spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image systems (top) and those for which no spectroscopic identifications of genuine multiple-image systems are yet available (bottom). Each subset of clusters contains half of the total sample of 10. Of the five clusters without any spectroscopically confirmed multiples, two contain convincing strong-lensing candidates: A 267 (E2) and A 1835 (K3). A firm lower limit on the fraction of clusters in this sample that contain a core region with a projected mass density above the critical density required for strong lensing is therefore 50 per cent, although fractions as high as \u223c70\u201380 per cent are also plausible.</p>                        <a id=\"17225302\" scrollto-destination=\"17225302\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\"
