class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image candidates and spectroscopic redshifts.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=wvWdhnYadatpduet4u2hzN-BRnhb13xdGE6z9NdvNY2WUNw7EvEjIBdmohDthcyI~i2ZqCAnYYyPjozon-ANuXO4TJvjhaGXn1RyO-Qmmmn1fmZzopzuJhQfY4ilSvKqWiZs1~LeSHQHbSaMRm5smRM4skkp8lyKZKWlUn5IHz8X50NYTrgQ42urP5Xsk3zdtgUFY53qIOoS1IlYSPlkw4XRBmynxqQsU8Z8ccH6NiorkwR6nhjYNcWnnkBVpR~af45tlYJygBShodbZrJ-AMKmmOdp0Y~dhYpQwgh2t6Oig9QX7XquViNHh9AcK5H3JcY4lf-kHgx90QkjQqslItg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multiple-image candidates and spectroscopic redshifts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225302/359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225302\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=fbw0ZPQBLG~HQWsHUYRS37-y8U0FyQT5m5qHyJkOIh5Nu-ELpM6D-4eIQuvijYcdANpLv2etKR~sV3XPEqMeHFzw22KVkR~06G1ft7zb2D1nE3tt-FrwOH1Kbr92N~r6Ao3NpfS94LJUkPiH5ot~b6TdRxwNp5wRGxmzIc1GyuAzCwJd19RpYTk2QKEeGzflxHl35QBQMODYVXBncq5md8rXMkCdFJVwiBUgZmQIJMM9ZdK~NI-dvEg-AGAAYqjRBE0Ep5JkeKsHFsO4h-eJ9D523yjLv3f-DP1qnJiyF~cS~eP0QefCD97SfqGTjVLlMhd12MgwwCfUYTSG1aNSXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225302&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl002.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image candidates and spectroscopic redshifts.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> also lists the spectroscopic redshifts that are available from other articles in this series (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2001, 2002b</a>), and the published literature. We refer the interested reader to these articles for the details of the spectroscopy and multiple-image interpretation. Note that some of the previously published multiple-image identifications were based on ground-based data, and therefore suffered from quite severe uncertainties. We discuss in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a> improvements to the interpretation of the data that are now possible using the <em>HST</em> data presented here. We also present below new spectroscopic identifications of four multiple-image candidates, recently obtained with the Keck and Subaru telescopes.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225308 id=\"17225308\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-1>3.2.1 Keck-I/LRIS observations of A 68</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">On 2002 November 30, we conducted deep multislit spectroscopy with the Low Resolution Imager Spectrograph (LRIS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oke et al. 1995</a>) on the Keck-I telescope,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><!----></a> on the cluster A 68. The night had reasonable seeing, \u223c0.8 arcsec, but was not photometric (with some cirrus), thus no spectrophotometric standard stars were observed. A 68 was observed for a total of 7.2 ks using the D680 dichroic with the 600/7500 grating on the red side and the 400/3400 grism on the blue side. On the red side the spectral dispersion was 1.28 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> with a spatial resolution of 0.214 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>, and on the blue side, the spectral dispersion was 1.09 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> with a spatial resolution of 0.135 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> using the blue sensitive 2 k \u00d7 4 k Marconi CCDs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Three multiple-image candidates were targeted in the mask: C0ab, C1c and C4 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>). Only C4 has a strong spectral feature \u2013 a single strong emission line at \u03bb<sub>obs</sub> = 4404.7 \u00c5 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). We interpret this line as Ly\u03b1\u03bb1216 at <em>z</em> = 2.625. The only other possibility would be [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] at <em>z</em> = 0.18, i.e. in front of the cluster. We consider this the less likely option given the apparent tangential distortion of the arclet with respect to the cluster centre, and the presence of C3 and C20 which appear to be lensed galaxies at a similar redshift to C4 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>). We note, however, that it appears these three arclets are each single images of different background galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"17225312\" scrollto-destination=\"17225312\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig005.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=ndW7IIYjupFgr8yZTzlCV0CtNy0W6VwtazZJFOw~x55gjBNncHzgitUdaviszT1vlYna5QnBFqeF3N-ETxCE5VCYW6aPRR3qTsOS~r91zztleLmahEIlieDSUv6jEjZIHwRtXgAsLMFsSjru8BtIBuHpIwIAa3sapdWAbvov~dErz1O1dGswUVW3oeODP53SPyYMdb4jWyzE03Y1IMkFPRs7xgUVSpyWEfOSv5psSkU6oQdk9DwxlLIOItGwXna9XocssWD683rPAOLr81gsmXODdeD9ILyNOughayiLAQ7wX6ZfB8ys86n-8AOSXXo1cPP7tME8-XAK6Tuy2MXBfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional spectrum of C4 in A 68, obtained with LRIS. We interpret the single strong emission line as Ly\u03b1 at z = 2.625 (see Section 3.2 for more details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225312/359-2-417-fig005.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225312\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig005.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=FUPJnfrFJ2D7M-wfCspbKDRLDAXmyslbqoF7WKDuxi5dyde55xevAhl9P1zQRBgNhoXmMr27Mcqvqcntxw39iHEKFLoR94icSHIjLazIrZCasyIBGj6FqUqAVFqxwP7UEFlLTE4bjht7F4LCe9EQMdI-tL4mmFy3686cjbKBnrkRwwKPm03MR72MPEgTcyLNOB7~Pqh9RMyBuZYncRi6DfFNaDJybMw-JYslBmjsHI4hEUcMeMcVMoheloLvmTR4nIJKF02-wAqHz8XjuKA3C~7r01XzKi6Xu1X8oae7NYe4UL6LxmMhaH~ZeYgDA6H4QN321DHFoodyxdSiAOnxgw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225312&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional spectrum of C4 in A 68, obtained with LRIS. We interpret the single strong emission line as Ly\u03b1 at <em>z</em> = 2.625 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a> for more details).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig005.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=ndW7IIYjupFgr8yZTzlCV0CtNy0W6VwtazZJFOw~x55gjBNncHzgitUdaviszT1vlYna5QnBFqeF3N-ETxCE5VCYW6aPRR3qTsOS~r91zztleLmahEIlieDSUv6jEjZIHwRtXgAsLMFsSjru8BtIBuHpIwIAa3sapdWAbvov~dErz1O1dGswUVW3oeODP53SPyYMdb4jWyzE03Y1IMkFPRs7xgUVSpyWEfOSv5psSkU6oQdk9DwxlLIOItGwXna9XocssWD683rPAOLr81gsmXODdeD9ILyNOughayiLAQ7wX6ZfB8ys86n-8AOSXXo1cPP7tME8-XAK6Tuy2MXBfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional spectrum of C4 in A 68, obtained with LRIS. We interpret the single strong emission line as Ly\u03b1 at z = 2.625 (see Section 3.2 for more details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225312/359-2-417-fig005.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225312\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig005.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=FUPJnfrFJ2D7M-wfCspbKDRLDAXmyslbqoF7WKDuxi5dyde55xevAhl9P1zQRBgNhoXmMr27Mcqvqcntxw39iHEKFLoR94icSHIjLazIrZCasyIBGj6FqUqAVFqxwP7UEFlLTE4bjht7F4LCe9EQMdI-tL4mmFy3686cjbKBnrkRwwKPm03MR72MPEgTcyLNOB7~Pqh9RMyBuZYncRi6DfFNaDJybMw-JYslBmjsHI4hEUcMeMcVMoheloLvmTR4nIJKF02-wAqHz8XjuKA3C~7r01XzKi6Xu1X8oae7NYe4UL6LxmMhaH~ZeYgDA6H4QN321DHFoodyxdSiAOnxgw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225312&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig005.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional spectrum of C4 in A 68, obtained with LRIS. We interpret the single strong emission line as Ly\u03b1 at <em>z</em> = 2.625 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a> for more details).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225316 id=\"17225316\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-2>3.2.2 Subaru/FOCAS observations of A 2219</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">On 2001 May 29\u201330, we conducted deep multislit spectroscopy of A 2219 with the Faint Object Camera and Spectrograph (FOCAS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kashikawa et al. 2002</a>) on the Subaru 8.3-m telescope.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><!----></a> The two nights had reasonable seeing, FWHM \u2243 0.8 arcsec, but were not fully photometric (with some cirrus), nevertheless we obtained a crude flux calibration using the spectrophotometric standard star \u2018Wolf 1346\u2019.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed A 2219 for a total of 12.6 ks using the Medium Blue (300 B mm<sup>\u22121</sup>) grism and the order sorting filter Y47. We used the MIT 2 k \u00d7 4 k CCD detector with a binning factor of 3 in <em>x</em> and 2 in <em>y</em>, which gives us a spectral dispersion of 2.8 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> and a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. Four multiple image candidates were targeted in the mask: P0 and P2c had previously been identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1995a)</a> as gravitational arcs, and P3/P4 had been identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00e9zecourt et al. (2000)</a> as lying at <em>z</em> = 3.6 \u00b1 0.4 using photometric redshift techniques. We list the results of our observations (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"17225321\" scrollto-destination=\"17225321\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig006.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=rmJPURfgVVwxxkGIshTcv7zzl4KmELpWXkLvWJQAVIVG6ppV0sSzBW099iSfkzmtMcmSAna0FoKPzEkvULpjrPgXI7cyeB-JHcJOGAJQY4cvXl6Xre98GrrEEUGbCnW7pIqIyAcuqaImWwozvK7RxW~t-x1viTs6ExOfSgu6G1uYgeATzXlPBb57Pxdu7MTVAuvOZKxqE3~rUENB7F8Yo2TkDtWVnvDesiFnjpaDklc3wTwftuaW4Wdhv3g8J-bkoPxAKsflXjEfO~bmCB7PJBHRmi9kiOuGdVBtkom0RznjkYvag9ZtYQZxDS6fs2ILh4nXc-gvfCUmvb88x5sJ4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional spectra of P0 (left), P2c (centre) and P3 (right) multiple-image systems in A 2219, obtained with the FOCAS spectrograph on Subaru. The vertical dotted lines in each panel mark the features used to identify the redshift of each system; the details of these identifications is discussed in Section 3.2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225321/359-2-417-fig006.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225321\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig006.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=P4tc6GPTJEgoYwqUH2D9u0RMez8WkCYzTy4dTA~KG8C~ZrLAGZbNAvsuu12YtMQwCXknVwmVKp68QgjfnvsZrdGTP9J3fj0abddUK62wFwCWGizxz1WZuc6NNsIgMcyIn4KStMt6LKfMlxiyBOx2XTuWueSalqSi5eYaJWhK7wjp4nR0RiaxhgV5dP1Lr1Cdq3W4Lj8xKDK-Syp6vpZq6KHzOL7VoArkyA6kMUlUWv4hI4xcNb~TFT5U2CTX-BYB2jPmHmEo6mak9mXDWs4d8XPKYvnpeULjFHWqa4aLGnFaTJEhTiCHJ-L2sMwJKuldY2o5xKTQvmY9uUjJNJrFrA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225321&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional spectra of P0 (left), P2c (centre) and P3 (right) multiple-image systems in A 2219, obtained with the FOCAS spectrograph on Subaru. The vertical dotted lines in each panel mark the features used to identify the redshift of each system; the details of these identifications is discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig006.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=rmJPURfgVVwxxkGIshTcv7zzl4KmELpWXkLvWJQAVIVG6ppV0sSzBW099iSfkzmtMcmSAna0FoKPzEkvULpjrPgXI7cyeB-JHcJOGAJQY4cvXl6Xre98GrrEEUGbCnW7pIqIyAcuqaImWwozvK7RxW~t-x1viTs6ExOfSgu6G1uYgeATzXlPBb57Pxdu7MTVAuvOZKxqE3~rUENB7F8Yo2TkDtWVnvDesiFnjpaDklc3wTwftuaW4Wdhv3g8J-bkoPxAKsflXjEfO~bmCB7PJBHRmi9kiOuGdVBtkom0RznjkYvag9ZtYQZxDS6fs2ILh4nXc-gvfCUmvb88x5sJ4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional spectra of P0 (left), P2c (centre) and P3 (right) multiple-image systems in A 2219, obtained with the FOCAS spectrograph on Subaru. The vertical dotted lines in each panel mark the features used to identify the redshift of each system; the details of these identifications is discussed in Section 3.2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225321/359-2-417-fig006.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225321\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig006.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=P4tc6GPTJEgoYwqUH2D9u0RMez8WkCYzTy4dTA~KG8C~ZrLAGZbNAvsuu12YtMQwCXknVwmVKp68QgjfnvsZrdGTP9J3fj0abddUK62wFwCWGizxz1WZuc6NNsIgMcyIn4KStMt6LKfMlxiyBOx2XTuWueSalqSi5eYaJWhK7wjp4nR0RiaxhgV5dP1Lr1Cdq3W4Lj8xKDK-Syp6vpZq6KHzOL7VoArkyA6kMUlUWv4hI4xcNb~TFT5U2CTX-BYB2jPmHmEo6mak9mXDWs4d8XPKYvnpeULjFHWqa4aLGnFaTJEhTiCHJ-L2sMwJKuldY2o5xKTQvmY9uUjJNJrFrA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225321&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig006.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional spectra of P0 (left), P2c (centre) and P3 (right) multiple-image systems in A 2219, obtained with the FOCAS spectrograph on Subaru. The vertical dotted lines in each panel mark the features used to identify the redshift of each system; the details of these identifications is discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><span class=\"label\">(i)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">P0 is identified as a <em>z</em> = 1.069 \u00b1 0.001 star-forming galaxy showing a strong [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb3727 emission plus weak Balmer and calcium lines.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(ii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">P2c is identified as a <em>z</em> = 2.730 \u00b1 0.001 galaxy using the following interstellar metal absorption lines: O <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u03bb1302.17, Si <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>\u03bb\u03bb1393.7, 1397.0, Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u03bb1608.45, C <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u03bb1656.93 and Al <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u03bb1670.79.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(iii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">P3 is identified as a <em>z</em> = 3.666 \u00b1 0.001 galaxy using a broad Ly\u03b1 absorption feature and the metal absorption lines O <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u03bb1302.17, Si <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>\u03bb\u03bb1393.7, 1397.0, plus C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>\u03bb\u03bb1548.2, 1550.77 in emission with a broad absorption feature on the blue side.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(iv)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">P4 was also observed, although it appears that the slit was not well aligned with the target galaxy, possibly due to a mask-milling problem. We do, however, detect an absorption feature in these data at the same wavelength as the Ly\u03b1 absorption feature in P3. It therefore appears that P4 is also at <em>z</em> = 3.666.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We interpret P0 as a pair of merging images straddling the <em>z</em> = 1.07 critical line. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1995a)</a> proposed that P1 is the counter-image of this pair; however, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00e9zecourt et al. (2000)</a> argued against P1 because its optical/near-infrared colours are redder than those of P0. When constraining the lens model of this cluster with just this multiple-image system, several alternative counter-images provided plausible fits. However, when this constraint was combined with other multiple-image systems, especially P3/P4/P5 which also lies in the saddle region between the BCG and the group of galaxies to the south-west, an acceptable model was only possible if P1 is identified as the counter-image of P0. The contradiction between this result and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00e9zecourt et al.'s (2000)</a> photometry is eliminated by the <em>HST</em> data, because it reveals that P1 is a disc galaxy, the southern portion (presumably part of the disc) of which has a surface brightness consistent with that of P0. This is confirmed by inspection of a colour image of this field based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Czoske's (2002)</a><em>BRI</em>-band CFH12k imaging of this cluster, which reveals that the southern envelope of P1 is also bluer than the central region, and is consistent with this interpretation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectroscopic identifications of P3 and P4 confirm <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00e9zecourt et al.'s (2000)</a> photometric redshifts. We identify P5 as the third image of this galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225328 id=\"17225328\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3 Source extraction and analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the multiple-image constraints described in the previous section, we also need to construct catalogues of cluster galaxies and faint, weakly lensed galaxies. The former are incorporated into the gravitational lens models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>) as galaxy-scale perturbations to the overall cluster potential. The latter supplement the multiple-image systems to further constrain the parameters of the lens models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The first step toward the cluster and background galaxy catalogues is to analyse the <em>HST</em> frames using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>). We selected all objects with isophotal areas in excess of 7 pixel (0.017 arcsec<sup>2</sup>) at the \u03bc<sub>702</sub> = 25.2 mag arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup> isophote (1.5\u03c3 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>). All detections centroided within 3 arcsec of the edge of the field of view, and within regions affected by diffraction spikes associated with bright stars are discarded, leaving a total of 8730 \u2018good\u2019 detections, of which 193 are classified as stars. We estimate from the roll-over in the number counts at faint limits, and Monte Carlo simulations of our ability to recover artificial faint test sources with <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span>, that the 80 per cent completeness limit of the <em>HST</em> frames is <em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u2243 26. We also use a simple model that combines the behaviour of deep <em>R</em>-band field galaxy counts (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1995b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hogg et al. 1997</a>) with a composite cluster luminosity function with a faint end slope of \u03b1= 1 (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Adami et al. 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Goto et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">De Propris et al. 2003</a>) to determine at what magnitude limit to divide the source catalogues into bright and faint subsamples. We adopt <em>R</em><sub>702</sub> = 22, which corresponds to 3.5 mag fainter than an <em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup> galaxy at the cluster redshift. We estimate conservatively that 20 per cent of the sources fainter than this limit may be cluster galaxies, thus contaminating the sample used for the weak-lensing constraints. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2</a> we verify that this contamination has a negligible effect on our results.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225335 id=\"17225335\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3-1>3.3.1 Cluster galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass of the galaxy-scale mass components in the lens models generally scale with their luminosity (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix A</a> for details). We therefore apply two corrections to the <em>R</em><sub>702</sub>-band <span class=\"small-caps\">mag_best</span> magnitudes of the bright galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>) to obtain robust measurements of the luminosities of the cluster galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Balogh et al. (2002)</a> fitted parametrized bulge and disc surface brightness profiles using <span class=\"small-caps\">gim2d</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Simard 1998</a>) to the cluster galaxies in this sample. We compare the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span><span class=\"small-caps\">mag_best</span> values in our bright galaxy catalogues (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>) with Balogh et al.'s surface photometry of the same galaxies, finding that <span class=\"small-caps\">mag_best</span> is fainter than the corresponding <span class=\"small-caps\">gim2d</span> magnitude. Typically \u0394<em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u223c 0.1\u20130.2, increasing to \u0394<em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u223c 0.5\u20131.5 for the brightest cluster members including the BCGs. These differences arise because <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> overestimates the sky background for the brighter and thus larger cluster galaxies, because as the size of these galaxies approaches the mesh size used for constructing the local background map, source flux is absorbed into the background. A second problem occurs in crowded cluster cores. When a smaller galaxy is de-blended from a brighter galaxy, <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> often incorrectly associates pixels from the brighter galaxy with the fainter one, thus overestimating the flux from fainter ones and underestimating the flux from brighter galaxies. We therefore adopt Balogh et al.'s surface photometry as the total <em>R</em><sub>702</sub>-band magnitudes of the cluster galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Optical photometry is more sensitive to ongoing star formation in cluster galaxies than NIR photometry. To gain a more reliable measure of stellar mass in the cluster galaxies we therefore exploit <em>K</em>-band imaging of the cluster fields, obtained as part of our search for gravitationally lensed EROs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2002a</a>), to convert the total <em>R</em><sub>702</sub>-band magnitudes to total <em>K</em>-band magnitudes. We subtract the 2-arcsec aperture (<em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u2212<em>K</em>) colours of the cluster galaxies measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2002a)</a> from the total <em>R</em><sub>702</sub>-band magnitudes to obtain total <em>K</em>-band magnitudes. Finally, we convert these magnitudes to rest-frame <em>K</em>-band luminosities, adopting <em>M</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub><em>K</em></sub> = (\u221223.38 \u00b1 0.03) + 5 log <em>h</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cole et al. 2001</a>) and <em>M</em><sub><em>K</em></sub><sub>\u2299</sub> = 3.39 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Johnson 1966</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1973</a>) and estimating <em>K</em>-corrections from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mannucci et al. (2001)</a>. Summing in quadrature all of the uncertainties arising from these conversions, we estimate that the <em>K</em>-band luminosity of an <em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup> galaxy is good to 10 per cent.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225341 id=\"17225341\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3-2>3.3.2 Faint galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we develop and apply several corrections to recover robust shape measurements of the faint galaxies for use as weak-lensing constraints on the cluster mass distributions. The goal of these corrections is to remove any artificial enhancement or suppression of image ellipticities from the faint galaxy catalogues. Such effects arise from the geometry of the focal plane, isotropic and anisotropic components of the PSF and pixelization of faint galaxy images. A correction for the geometric distortion of the focal plane was applied in the data reduction pipeline using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Trauger et al.'s (1995)</a> polynomial solution (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.1</a>). We deal with the remaining issues in turn below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 PSF varies spatially and temporally at the \u223c10 and \u223c2 per cent levels, respectively (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rhodes, Refregier &amp; Groth 2000</a>). We ignore the temporal component because, as we demonstrate below using simulations, point source ellipticities of \u223c2 per cent are comparable with the noise on the shape measurements. We examine the spatial variation of the PSF in the 10 WFPC2 frames, however, each field only contains approximately six suitable isolated, high signal-to-noise ratio, unsaturated stars. We therefore exploit archival <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 observations of a further eight low-luminosity clusters (<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2264 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 0.1\u20132.4 keV) at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.25 (Cl 0818+56, Cl 0819+70, Cl 0841+70, Cl 0849+37, Cl 1309+32, Cl 1444+63, Cl 1701+64 and Cl 1702+64) that were observed in an identical manner to our cycle 8 observations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Balogh et al. 2002</a>). These data were processed identically to the primary science data and stringent selection criteria applied to the combined data set to construct a sample of 103 stars from which to derive a PSF correction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The PSFs of these stars are tangentially distorted with respect to the centre of each WFC chip with the magnitude of the distortion increasing with distance from each chip centre. The tangential shear at the edge of each chip is \u223c5\u201310 per cent, falling to \u22641\u20132 per cent at each chip centre, and the variation in the distortion pattern between the chips is negligible, in agreement with <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra et al. (1998)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rhodes et al. (2000)</a>. We therefore stack the three chips to derive a global solution by fitting a second-order polynomial to the tangential shear as a function of distance from the chip centre (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>). After applying this correction to the entire star sample from all 18 cluster fields, the median tangential shear of the stars is reduced to the same level as the radial stellar shear, i.e. \u22641\u20132 per cent. We interpret the residuals as random noise and test this hypothesis using Monte Carlo simulations. We insert 10<sup>4</sup> stellar profiles that are sheared in small increments between 0 and 10 per cent into random blank-sky positions in our science frames. We then run the same <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> detection algorithm as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a> on these frames. These simulations reveal that the position angle of a nearly circular stellar source can only be measured to \u226410 per cent accuracy if the ellipticity of the source is \u22652.5 per cent, thus confirming our interpretation of the residuals. We use the results of this analysis to correct the shape measurements in the faint galaxy catalogues. The corrections all result in a change of \u22640.02 in the final weak shear constraints listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>; i.e. smaller than or comparable to the statistical uncertainties.</p>                        <a id=\"17225347\" scrollto-destination=\"17225347\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig007.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=Ub2~IgNS9TuynEuFEkZ05rjLZCe4YYEn7dL6wMz4Yw1eXyA4ax~ORv8v4ngpVqQfT~049fV-Lc~5Q1w76MG7tKyaMb8XvpRLHZ3oYHqOVnL~uTELn9gOOk8cfuo20ZLvTJT1jsXYyVhwsYuXJMchQdBP2MZEswLlV1PED1lBgLoh2x4ZNdPfKLN8Iqx8w8vvdKuGOUPKXtnO5iZxlqXocONfR0zBEn22rnNNJONsMJl5su3Lgh4oCknuWm8AjvasBTKzagVGmCzwxhBgi1sOccz7QhI1-h5gn55TVcK7f0z8xg6XKRv-97n1gjTY2SJfiWy4Bw3hgIBgtkUT1lOb~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: mean tangential shear, \u03c4u,raw, of the high signal-to-noise ratio star sample as a function of radial distance from the stacked chip centre. The dashed line shows the polynomial fit to these data that we used to remove the PSF anisotropy. Right: the results of Monte Carlo simulations to test how accurately we can measure the ellipticity of faint galaxies. The measured ellipticity as a fraction of the true ellipticity is well fitted by a second-order polynomial function (dashed curve). When the galaxy image is smaller than \u223c30 pixel, the shape measurements are overwhelmed by the PSF and the effects of pixelization. We therefore cut our faint galaxy catalogues at a \u2018faint\u2019 limit of area \u2265 30 pixel. We also use the polynomial function plotted in this figure to correct the observed ellipticities to intrinsic ellipticities.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig007.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225347/359-2-417-fig007.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig007.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225347\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig007.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=SUb5-U2SytKSa6Rce10vdjv-ZQgCr43xpu3apVB7y56e3hIZLCDw3ratdW8NHknSpOp4VsnfyAPr-BIZ9gwLKjYTcjG4fUt50XrTEtR0e9DZ-Eso88NLo0kzhe71s3snlhcNg2XI2ugd5zfHSJW8zbGWj4GaE5NxvnkIKg3udCQAgGY-TiLmBYllcEHg3GaCs~8TnIVPjwIWgAWFU-I0DklIqHtZ7d~bTqaj-NiV54fqimObBkX7bO7RkGCRM5cQilp46G1Dw5MnSyfQx0~0YjZFxfV4dKXDtYvJ-5uf3Nkta4rPZHBOyrd~-gmP6SZsZVJ2ujr1~eSAIc0TEzfrgg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225347&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig007.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: mean tangential shear, \u03c4<sub>u,raw</sub>, of the high signal-to-noise ratio star sample as a function of radial distance from the stacked chip centre. The dashed line shows the polynomial fit to these data that we used to remove the PSF anisotropy. Right: the results of Monte Carlo simulations to test how accurately we can measure the ellipticity of faint galaxies. We therefore cut our faint galaxy catalogues at a \u2018faint\u2019 limit of area \u2265 30 pixel. The dashed line shows the polynomial fit to these data that we used to remove the PSF anisotropy. Right: the results of Monte Carlo simulations to test how accurately we can measure the ellipticity of faint galaxies. The measured ellipticity as a fraction of the true ellipticity is well fitted by a second-order polynomial function (dashed curve). When the galaxy image is smaller than \u223c30 pixel, the shape measurements are overwhelmed by the PSF and the effects of pixelization. We therefore cut our faint galaxy catalogues at a \u2018faint\u2019 limit of area \u2265 30 pixel. We also use the polynomial function plotted in this figure to correct the observed ellipticities to intrinsic ellipticities.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"17225348\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225348/359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225348\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=0D3PAsF9En~uJ3GBbTW3kHQnWs~XRsdz9uoAGszrvGg0v9k-EI3COvGzmg67K8uFCSozVf7nVj~ZvFBIYzanRoALsMCKo7L3c7pvo~zpAH52em9iHemg3SIJFzjt0QDE1paeaGK22khqaNG0QBn5lWXI-YhKr9PO4vcaXJc3mjpVzB85O4P4VP6hk8g5jPjQKlZGK~RCsVaMGNzmONKA0WAvAkDAHrtlWSg5iUWSzoyTK-8RuRV4x0~AirDpDWvlKVw~ri6DHhH6wdsQTFKhJnFusQY1Z6RxBYs-TaI2VkkepaIqiiJu7IFla~ZY3DoDDB5h2~2-~ffDdgtxaZTuzA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225348&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of lens model constraints.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=LR213M4Y9PV-sENY6myn1dJhqFM-ipuCoXpL0yR1B6eVPt5bCEj0zaXclGOTkUd5w6Qxg6tKtkUMVfn-HANwaIktrTVQCCbE10UAoJ4nHunpvO1Df1VoJZZxZ8SWaTjqUqArKRY0yKbiLIGGIljUbasMBm1mHrTLo4A6F6mYl7VyZ7vcq6sccJeOlPOW6SL86UpXTgQjvTa3ml54ik8YHlnmm0N4DefeL9bT13O-zVhKoMzgQftSuj36wxugNvDytptWcs4T7erUcADBcEIND-wZDqudd3tLr3dZkrzjU50CHGjPzTHkd1TNHJBRMc5afPuFZhQ6mNUjW4NXYc355A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of lens model constraints.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225348/359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225348\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=0D3PAsF9En~uJ3GBbTW3kHQnWs~XRsdz9uoAGszrvGg0v9k-EI3COvGzmg67K8uFCSozVf7nVj~ZvFBIYzanRoALsMCKo7L3c7pvo~zpAH52em9iHemg3SIJFzjt0QDE1paeaGK22khqaNG0QBn5lWXI-YhKr9PO4vcaXJc3mjpVzB85O4P4VP6hk8g5jPjQKlZGK~RCsVaMGNzmONKA0WAvAkDAHrtlWSg5iUWSzoyTK-8RuRV4x0~AirDpDWvlKVw~ri6DHhH6wdsQTFKhJnFusQY1Z6RxBYs-TaI2VkkepaIqiiJu7IFla~ZY3DoDDB5h2~2-~ffDdgtxaZTuzA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225348&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl003.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of lens model constraints.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also use Monte Carlo simulations to estimate the minimum number of contiguous pixels required for a reliable shape measurement (\u226410 per cent uncertainty). We first select a sample of relatively bright (<em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u223c 19\u201321) background galaxies to use as test objects, ensuring that these galaxies cover the observed range of ellipticities in deep field galaxy surveys (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels 1998</a>). We scale and insert these test objects into random blank-sky positions in the science frames and attempt to detect them by running <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> in the same configuration as used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>. We perform \u223c10<sup>6</sup> realizations spanning the full range of expected apparent magnitudes and scale sizes of faint galaxies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1995b</a>). The measured ellipticity declines markedly as a fraction of the input ellipticity for sources with areas smaller than \u223c1000 pixel. Also, the smallest galaxy area for which the uncertainty in its shape measurement is \u226410 per cent is \u223c30 pixel. This limit represents, for the expected ellipticity distribution (0 \u2264\u03c4\u2264 1.5; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels 1998</a>), the minimum galaxy size for which both the minor and major axes are resolved by <em>HST</em>/WFPC2. We therefore adopt 30 contiguous pixels as the \u2018faint\u2019 limit of our background galaxy catalogues. We also fit a second-order polynomial to the simulation results in the range 30 \u2264 area \u2264 10<sup>3</sup> pixel (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>), and use this recovery function to correct the measured ellipticity of each source in the faint galaxy catalogues.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225355 id=\"17225355\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4>3.4 Summary of lens model constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we briefly summarize the strong-lensing constraints and then describe how the faint galaxy catalogues constructed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3.2</a> are converted into constraints on the cluster mass distributions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The multiple-image systems (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>) comprise two categories: confirmed and unconfirmed. Confirmed multiples have a spectroscopic redshift and all the counter-images are either identified or lie fainter than the detection threshold of the observations. The morphology of candidate multiples strongly suggests that they are multiply imaged, but the redshift of these systems is less well defined (\u0394<em>z</em> \u2265 0.1) and not all counter-images may be identified. The confirmed systems provide constraints on both the absolute projected mass within an aperture centred on the clusters and the shape of the underlying mass distribution; in contrast, the unconfirmed systems place additional constraints on the shape of the cluster potential. Both categories of multiple-image constraints probe only the central <em>R</em> \u2264 50\u2013100 kpc of each cluster. Therefore, to extend the constraints to larger radii, we supplement the strong-lensing constraints with the weakly sheared background galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To use the weakly sheared galaxies as model constraints, we need to estimate their redshifts. For that purpose, we use the Hubble Deep Field North (HDF-N) photometric redshift catalogue of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fern\u00e1ndez-Soto, Lanzetta &amp; Yahil (1999)</a>. The <em>N</em><sub>pixels</sub> \u2265 30 limit developed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3.2</a> is equivalent to a magnitude limit of <em>R</em><sub>702</sub> \u2264 26. Using a simple no-evolution model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">King &amp; Ellis 1985</a>) we estimate that a typical galaxy at <em>z</em>\u223c 0.5\u20131.5 has a colour of (<em>R</em><sub>702</sub>\u2212<em>I</em><sub>814</sub>) \u2243 0.7 in the Vega system; converting to <em>AB</em> magnitudes, this translates into a faint limit of <em>I</em><sub>814,<em>AB</em></sub> \u2264 25.8 in the HDF-N catalogue. The median redshift to this limit is <em>z</em><sub>median</sub> = 0.9, with an uncertainty of \u223c0.2, stemming from the dispersion in galaxy colours at <em>z</em>\u223c 0.5\u20131.5 and an uncertainty in the conversion between the <em>N</em><sub>pixels</sub> \u2265 30 and <em>R</em><sub>702</sub> \u2264 26. We therefore adopt <em>z</em> = 0.9 \u00b1 0.2 as the fiducial redshift of the faint galaxy catalogues. Note that the uncertainty in the median redshift contributes just 10\u201320 per cent of the total error budget, which is dominated by the statistical uncertainty in the shear measurements. For each cluster we also examine the region occupied by multiple-image systems in the <em>HST</em> frames and choose a minimum cluster-centric radius (<em>R</em><sub>min</sub>) for the inclusion of faint galaxies in the model constraints. We test the robustness of these choices by perturbing the <em>R</em><sub>min</sub> values by \u00b110 arcsec to ensure that the mean weak shear computed from the galaxies lying exterior to <em>R</em><sub>min</sub> is insensitive to the perturbation in <em>R</em><sub>min</sub>. The maximum cluster-centric radius of the faint galaxies included in the weak-lensing constraints lies in the range 440\u2013580 kpc depending on the cluster redshift and is typically 500 kpc, which corresponds to 2 arcmin at <em>z</em> = 0.2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We summarize the strong- and weak-lensing model constraints in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>, which is the key output from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. First, it defines, on the basis of our analysis of the <em>HST</em> data and ground-based spectroscopic follow-up which of the multiple-image constraints can be used to calibrate the absolute mass of the clusters, and which may be used only for constraining the shape of the cluster potentials. Secondly, it lists how many faint galaxies and from what observed regions of the clusters they have been selected to provide the weak-lensing constraints. The strength of the weak-lensing signal is also listed as the mean tangential shear, \u3008\u03c4<sub>u</sub>\u3009. In the next section we explain how we use these constraints to model the distribution of mass in the cluster cores.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225360 id=\"17225360\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 Gravitational Lens Modelling</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> ray-tracing code (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib 1993</a>) supplemented by additional routines to incorporate weak-lensing constraints (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith 2002</a>) to build detailed parametrized models of the cluster mass distributions. We refer the interested reader to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix A</a> for full details of the modelling method. Here, we explain the modelling process in more general terms.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each model comprises a number of parametrized mass components which account for mass distributed on both cluster and galaxy scales. The cluster-scale mass components represent mass associated with the cluster as a whole, i.e. DM and hot gas in the ICM. The galaxy-scale mass components account for perturbations to the cluster potential by the galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A \u03c7<sup>2</sup>-estimator quantifies how well each trial lens model fits the data, and is minimized by varying the model parameters to obtain an acceptable [\u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u2243 1 per degree of freedom (dof)] fit to the observational constraints. This is an iterative process, which we begin by restricting our attention to the least ambiguous model constraints (i.e. the confirmed multiple-image systems) and the relevant free parameters. For example, in a typical cluster lens there will be one spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image system and a few other candidate multiples. The model fitting process therefore begins with using the spectroscopic multiple to constrain the parameters of the main cluster-scale mass component. Once we have established an acceptable model using the confirmed multiple-image systems, we use this model to explore the other constraints and to search for further counter-images. Specifically, we test the predictive power of the model and use this to iterate towards the final refined model. At each stage of this process we incorporate additional constraints (e.g. faint image pairs) and the corresponding free parameters (e.g. the ellipticity and orientation of key mass components, or the velocity dispersion of cluster galaxies that lie close to faint image pairs) into the model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225364 id=\"17225364\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 Construction of the lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This section describes how the method outlined above and described in detail in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix A</a> was applied to each cluster in our sample. The parameters and the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of each fiducial best-fitting model are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17225366\" scrollto-destination=\"17225366\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=nDz30IxJDTvO0o1LBtakM0X9sNvnu7Rz5kZla9LBUH2XkUBj7l7uxBbMKhQrvT3aFvr2Do-J1R6MKusV6TuJfvZvl9B3bbbR3NUdou-iUBDn9RvtVx~1R2wGZFZToSuY2j00J7yPxsLMvaZMQkzyEW9JW3Znzh9y4~rLR7uGR5gXWFAXtV5avCPh~s0LAymO0rBdOeYD2QDvFZz-Yd-fPxd5HGhW68vVoz6TzTwB8tjaJYG8~FyrdexVAh0UjdjfWZQKCy8dtGdpZqEQPbu~MR8hB1ExD8oJdbPMf5UtKBUWnfAD~7iOQxzpcRJNjFgIkD8B4SVOZ~vqNMsJDoLJ1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fitting parameters of the fiducial lens models.a\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225366/359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225366\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=M1mj7Ur0D0aW84Ni2~yAT7SrdSTK9i8WzwwmWfVuHXS8aYeWfTACudpXLZxJmouvNveZIQ~mMTzUFhgLPEq7denrmg~qG-J853gRStNrBewloL55ELGAsLQKMMSfINBW7DVNO0ZaaYhZkmvJtN4kvZw97dY~igi8bTfK8Gf6Kb9F8DWKTmqyAFvttXN0q0cFhwkCKuOANZARTItd6NiB3Yup2xVe2-sU3IFwp8gu45MXNdDQRBtMeRRnjeHJb8ni1uc6mcyETTqEG-ZP12eNoxPCMfzdQa72s8nsoOghX4SP~YI~chu3Ga5hcrdQKrhnkRqN2x1jkyVSEk-Y9fGSag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225366&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the fiducial lens models.<sup><em>a</em></sup></p></div></div><div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=nDz30IxJDTvO0o1LBtakM0X9sNvnu7Rz5kZla9LBUH2XkUBj7l7uxBbMKhQrvT3aFvr2Do-J1R6MKusV6TuJfvZvl9B3bbbR3NUdou-iUBDn9RvtVx~1R2wGZFZToSuY2j00J7yPxsLMvaZMQkzyEW9JW3Znzh9y4~rLR7uGR5gXWFAXtV5avCPh~s0LAymO0rBdOeYD2QDvFZz-Yd-fPxd5HGhW68vVoz6TzTwB8tjaJYG8~FyrdexVAh0UjdjfWZQKCy8dtGdpZqEQPbu~MR8hB1ExD8oJdbPMf5UtKBUWnfAD~7iOQxzpcRJNjFgIkD8B4SVOZ~vqNMsJDoLJ1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fitting parameters of the fiducial lens models.a\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225366/359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225366\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=M1mj7Ur0D0aW84Ni2~yAT7SrdSTK9i8WzwwmWfVuHXS8aYeWfTACudpXLZxJmouvNveZIQ~mMTzUFhgLPEq7denrmg~qG-J853gRStNrBewloL55ELGAsLQKMMSfINBW7DVNO0ZaaYhZkmvJtN4kvZw97dY~igi8bTfK8Gf6Kb9F8DWKTmqyAFvttXN0q0cFhwkCKuOANZARTItd6NiB3Yup2xVe2-sU3IFwp8gu45MXNdDQRBtMeRRnjeHJb8ni1uc6mcyETTqEG-ZP12eNoxPCMfzdQa72s8nsoOghX4SP~YI~chu3Ga5hcrdQKrhnkRqN2x1jkyVSEk-Y9fGSag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225366&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl004.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the fiducial lens models.<sup><em>a</em></sup></p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 68 \u2013</strong> We first constrained the model with just the multiply imaged ERO at <em>z</em> = 1.6 (C0, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>), identifying nine distinct knots of likely star formation in each image of this galaxy. A model containing just one cluster-scale mass component (#1), did not fit these data well: \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof \u2265 5. We therefore added a second cluster-scale mass component (#2) to the north-west of the central galaxy. Despite the strong evidence for the presence of this mass component in the weak-shear map (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>), no single bright cluster galaxy dominates the group of galaxies found in this region. We therefore adopt the brightest of this group of galaxies as the centre of clump #2, for which we adopt a circular shape. C0 places strong constraints on the mass required in this second clump because the spatial configuration of the images is very sensitive to the details of the bi-modal mass structure of the cluster. We find an acceptable fit without optimizing the spatial parameters of clump #2. The south-western corner of C0 straddles the <em>z</em> = 1.6 radial caustic in this best-fitting lens model, causing an additional, radially amplified image of this portion of the galaxy to be predicted. We search the <em>HST</em> frame in the vicinity of the predicted radial image, and find a faint radial feature (C19) 4-arcsec north-west of the central galaxy which is consistent with the model prediction. Further constraining the model with C15/C16/C17, at <em>z</em> = 5.4 confirms the validity of the model thus far, and helps to constrain the spatial parameters of the NW cluster-scale mass component. This model is also able to reproduce the observed morphology of the other candidate multiple-image systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 209 \u2013</strong> Given the weak constraints on this cluster from the <em>HST</em> data, we restrict our attention to a simple model in which the velocity dispersion of the central cluster-scale mass component is the only free parameter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 267 \u2013</strong> The important difference between this cluster and A 209 is that it contains a candidate multiple-image pair (E2a/b). In addition to constraining the central velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>o</sub>) and core radius (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub>) for the central cluster-scale mass component we therefore use this image pair to constrain the shape of the cluster potential.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 383 \u2013</strong> We use the many constraints available for this cluster to determine precisely the full range of geometrical and dynamical parameters for the cluster scale and central galaxy mass components. Despite the overall relaxed appearance of this cluster, the bright cluster elliptical south-west of the central galaxy actually renders this a bi-modal cluster (albeit with very unequal masses) on small scales. We therefore also obtain a constraint on the velocity dispersion of this galaxy (A 383 #2 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al.'s (2004)</a> spectroscopic redshifts for B1a/b and B0b, placing them both at <em>z</em> = 1.01, i.e. the same redshift as B0a, slightly modifies <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al.'s (2001)</a> multiple-image interpretation of this cluster. However, the parameter space occupied by this cluster is consistent with that of Smith et al.'s model (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix B</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 773 \u2013</strong> Although no multiple-image systems have been identified yet in this cluster, the large number of early-type galaxies and the strength of the weak-shear signal suggest that this cluster is probably quite massive. First, we use the shapes of the weakly sheared galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>) to constrain a model that contains a single cluster-scale mass component centred on the BCG (A 773 #1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>). The best-fitting velocity dispersion of clump #1 in this model is \u223c1000 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. However, the spatial structure in the residuals reveals that this simple model does not reproduce the strong shear signal observed to the north of the second brightest cluster galaxy and to the east of the BCG, i.e. in the saddle region between the BCG and the group of cluster ellipticals at the eastern extreme of the WFPC2 field of view (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>). We therefore introduce two more cluster-scale mass components: A 773 #2 is coincident with the second brightest cluster elliptical and A 773 #3 coincides with the brightest member of the eastern group of galaxies. This model faithfully reproduces the global shear strength, and crucially it also reproduces the spatial variation of the shear and thus provides a superior description of the cluster potential than the initial simple model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 963 \u2013</strong> H0 provides a straightforward yet powerful constraint on the potential of this cluster, enabling the dynamical and spatial parameters of both the cluster-scale and BCG mass components to be constrained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 1763 \u2013</strong> This cluster is similar to A 209 in that there are no confirmed multiple-image systems and the weak-shear signal is relatively low (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>). We therefore fit a model that contains the velocity dispersion of the (single) cluster-scale mass component as the only free parameter. Overall, this simple model is an acceptable fit to the global weak-shear signal; however, it fails to reproduce the large observed shear signal to the west of the central galaxy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>). We interpret these residuals as a signature of substructure in this cluster, indicating that the mass distribution may be more complex than a single cluster-scale mass plus galaxies. Unfortunately, the weak-shear signal is not strong enough to place any further constraints on this cluster at this time.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 1835 \u2013</strong> The multiple-image interpretation of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schmidt, Allen &amp; Fabian (2001)</a> is ruled out by the new WFPC2 data presented in this paper, specifically, the differences in surface brightness between K0, K1 and K3. The absence of multiple-image constraints therefore results in a model similar to those of A 209 and A 1763, with just a single free parameter \u2013 the central velocity dispersion of the central cluster-scale mass component.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 2218 \u2013</strong> The model of A 2218 builds on the models published by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. (1995, 1996)</a> and incorporates for the first time the spectroscopic redshifts of the M2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels et al. 1998</a>) and M3 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ellis et al. 2001</a>) multiple-image systems. In addition to the central cluster-scale mass component (A 2218 #1), this model contains a second cluster-scale mass component (A 2218 #2) centred on the second brightest cluster galaxy which lies to the south-east of the BCG. The velocity dispersion and cut-off radius of the two bright cluster galaxies (A 2218 #3 and 4) that lie adjacent to the M0 multiple-image system are also included as free parameters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>A 2219 \u2013</strong> We first attempt to find an acceptable solution that is based on a single cluster-scale mass component centred on the BCG, constrained just by P0. This model succeeds in reproducing the straight morphology of P0 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>); however, when P3/P4/P5 are added to the constraints, the fit deteriorates substantially. We therefore add a second cluster-scale mass component (A 2219 #2) at the position of the second brightest cluster galaxy (south-east of the central galaxy). The second clump improves the fit somewhat, but the tight constraints from these two multiple-image systems on the saddle region between clumps #1 and 2 necessitate the addition of a third cluster-scale component (A 2219 #3, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>). This tri-modal model is a good fit, and readily accommodates the additional constraints from P2a/b/c with a minimum of further modifications. This best-fitting model is also able to reproduce faithfully the details of the candidate multiple-image systems.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225377 id=\"17225377\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 Calibration of weak-lensing constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We investigate the systematic uncertainty that may arise as a result of confirmed multiple-image systems not being available for all of the clusters. First, we focus on the five clusters for which both multiple-image and weak-shear constraints are available (A 68, A 383, A 963, A 2218, A 2219). We ignore the multiple-image constraints and construct a model of each of these clusters using just the weak-shear information. In common with the five-lens models that are based solely on weak-shear constraints (A 209, A 267, A 773, A 1763, A 1835) we find that the weak-shear signal alone can generally only constrain one free parameter (\u03c3<sub>o</sub>) per cluster-scale mass component. Individually, the velocity dispersions of the cluster-scale mass components in the weak-shear constrained models agree within the uncertainties with the velocity dispersions obtained in the multiple-image constrained models. However, when treated as an ensemble, the mean ratio of weak-shear constrained velocity dispersions to multiple-image constrained velocity dispersion is 0.94 \u00b1 0.04. Based on just five clusters, it therefore appears that \u03c3<sub>o</sub> for the cluster-scale mass components in the models of weak-shear-only clusters may be underestimated, on average, by \u223c6 per cent. Mass scales as \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>o</sub>; this possible systematic error in \u03c3<sub>o</sub> therefore translates into a possible \u223c12 per cent underestimate in cluster mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This uncertainty probably arises from contamination of the faint background galaxy catalogues by faint cluster galaxies, which we estimated conservatively to be \u223c20 per cent in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3</a>. Our cross-calibration of the strong- and weak-lensing constraints therefore suggests that the contamination is somewhat lower than previously thought. We choose not to correct the parameters of the weak-shear constrained models for this effect because the uncertainties in these models are dominated by the statistical uncertainty which is typically \u0394\u03c3<sub>o</sub>\u223c 10\u201320 per cent. A global 6 per cent correction to the velocity dispersions of the weak-lensing constrained cluster lens models would also neglect the dependence of the contamination, for a given cluster, on the optical richness of that cluster. This uncertainty has a negligible effect on the results that rely on cluster mass measurements (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225380 id=\"17225380\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 X-ray Data and Analysis</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We complement the detailed view of the distribution of total mass in the cluster cores that is now available to us from the lens models with high-resolution X-ray observations with <em>Chandra</em>. The purpose of including these data is to compare the underlying mass distribution derived from lensing with the properties of the ICM. Specifically, we wish to compare the mass and X-ray morphologies of the clusters, and to explore how the lensing-based mass measurements are correlated with the X-ray temperature of the clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We therefore retrieve archival <em>Chandra</em> data for all 10 clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>). In the spectral and imaging analysis we used only chips I0\u2013I3 and chip S3 for observations in ACIS-I and ACIS-S configurations, respectively. All of the <em>Chandra</em> observations were performed in the ACIS-I configuration except A 383 (ID: 2321), A 963 and A 1835 which were observed in the ACIS-S configuration. To reduce the data we used the procedures described by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch et al. (2000b)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch &amp; Vikhlinin (2001)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mazzotta et al. (2001)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin, Markevitch &amp; Murray (2001a)</a>. We note that the three observations of A 383 were not all performed in the same configuration. The spectral response and background for each observation were therefore generated individually before combining the data. The data were also cleaned for the presence of strong background flares following the prescription of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch et al. (2000a)</a>. The net exposure time for each observation is listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>. Adaptively smoothed flux contours are also overplotted on the <em>HST</em> frames in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17225383\" scrollto-destination=\"17225383\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=A7W4T~xZa3Utn7dmXR8mL0FMaTO1eLUjTXSt9O3k4v5i4unuH-7wZxs7yRsmj~AzgLj4k1J64o1cYwsx4-LX6EVlJsWI7jVi1ak5DEYDJjOIxCjzPpRB5Xr1XCdQwiY7DXnBYcvEZB3lhtkBomAYVDpWtTMtwaxBhyDT11bz8Jm7CwPr-A3sZQYmDPjKkBCWIBfivIKUry0n1mEYNac8YRtl-IeazlL46YylTn2~o5mZcsJwEkg49qbfazGjdTlpqAvgbuChkN4~ZdjcKdn2bfMOjFO1~LGZEELyT~3we-S03hoSrGwTFxIs5dnhrddndtbr~xOdYGlZMjmZs4czYg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of archival X-ray observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225383/359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225383\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=HtAB6Kp3zLKsUibARVrzq1J3HAnK6m~UeM3IGdS4uUXW9eBY0gi-KHVZOAQfqQRC1379kk-YqLuv1b~9YC0nTUnetcAMOxblE8RH5kewbJhFFf8gaWitC5xjT73YM6JUSuYvAbn7r0i7pVsypq5e0SrrAViAL0KLsgyIYaGDEJ3ih4HwlRdXcR6X~Jt8C3T8gXHQMPvoc6r4mZOo5c5AxOA8bfLNpdzR1m4SlopEKIP~~a9Oz46AUz8puwFWMMPx~y2JmSUepFqDq~gAiPIrO3ypnlFHNJQasDcM--gtop~4Or2H1p7WEDl1hztLGW1zmkJOnnGOPKppY4KC0FElxQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225383&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl005.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of archival X-ray observations.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"17225385\" scrollto-destination=\"17225385\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label
