observations.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"17225385\" scrollto-destination=\"17225385\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig008.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=NnSbSUG0Z2l0-RdUImXC4-I3Yx2W2m7pT4lR23NRE9TWobPBILLsBCkUqUvkSizk6tyrdQWp7cLyfVbFQc0yWIetMdjVFVm3XbASVmYZhdEnhNPdPi4DirGkPWTDod9Vm2Y0l8RcQGY2HuTrbSf3g7UAyXm~3dm3w8oCv7JzqCegwtM-tykLHqAFogjHBIUjXS-kjgS5AQtPLTkBTdp8-7WYbCfuMqMXHmppu8S9g2r1768kTVxdH4wl5Z2Jgl9x1EGHYQXS2ZgSBGR2pqFXlKACP9HSRNe7rbF2B49lSNd3lQ-NT7ZE~q0NAuAZJbsFlzP7Sel~p9teyKJabOiKOw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"For each cluster in the sample, we show (left) the adaptively smoothed X-ray flux contours and (right) the iso-mass contours calculated from the best-fitting lens models. The greyscales are low-resolution renderings of the HST/WFPC2 frame. All three of the clusters classified as relaxed (A 383, A 963 and A 1835; Table 6) have very regular and centrally concentrated X-ray and mass morphologies. The seven unrelaxed clusters all have irregular X-ray morphologies, and four of them (A 68, A 773, A 2218, A 2219) have bi-/tri-modal mass morphologies. All contours are equally spaced in the log.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225385/359-2-417-fig008.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225385\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig008.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=SHAW1eN3ZyBaFrwRtOAG3w9d0zwRQCAk-wPwPoKJJbXJSMKLFyKxRy800h0P0CgThJYnAEWGvBAFSlzDm0jNDgX2xE0cSTo4bPtFc-bOxzdXmtM0lNQ04jbXio1Jv-I1N7aQYhgBFgWRic13a-GYgc~dviEwX6QJaIdcpwgRSGsGQpf4jXVt3dS13Q94NZZ6NoHU0in2jHKqlACqQkjcfTGK6DOxmk6uoXdQAMlU1vUBrbFmciPZlL~sctZt8vhXfaxK3rGmuFd~VJ6SA1c2Xv9Bj4U8GEfr2o38jrljr7wN9mVgR3gofgq41~v5HzfoGZCvDxNkbz6s1LOWyEjH5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225385&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each cluster in the sample, we show (left) the adaptively smoothed X-ray flux contours and (right) the iso-mass contours calculated from the best-fitting lens models. The greyscales are low-resolution renderings of the <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 frame. All three of the clusters classified as relaxed (A 383, A 963 and A 1835; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>) have very regular and centrally concentrated X-ray and mass morphologies. The seven unrelaxed clusters all have irregular X-ray morphologies, and four of them (A 68, A 773, A 2218, A 2219) have bi-/tri-modal mass morphologies. All contours are equally spaced in the log.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig008.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=NnSbSUG0Z2l0-RdUImXC4-I3Yx2W2m7pT4lR23NRE9TWobPBILLsBCkUqUvkSizk6tyrdQWp7cLyfVbFQc0yWIetMdjVFVm3XbASVmYZhdEnhNPdPi4DirGkPWTDod9Vm2Y0l8RcQGY2HuTrbSf3g7UAyXm~3dm3w8oCv7JzqCegwtM-tykLHqAFogjHBIUjXS-kjgS5AQtPLTkBTdp8-7WYbCfuMqMXHmppu8S9g2r1768kTVxdH4wl5Z2Jgl9x1EGHYQXS2ZgSBGR2pqFXlKACP9HSRNe7rbF2B49lSNd3lQ-NT7ZE~q0NAuAZJbsFlzP7Sel~p9teyKJabOiKOw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"For each cluster in the sample, we show (left) the adaptively smoothed X-ray flux contours and (right) the iso-mass contours calculated from the best-fitting lens models. The greyscales are low-resolution renderings of the HST/WFPC2 frame. All three of the clusters classified as relaxed (A 383, A 963 and A 1835; Table 6) have very regular and centrally concentrated X-ray and mass morphologies. The seven unrelaxed clusters all have irregular X-ray morphologies, and four of them (A 68, A 773, A 2218, A 2219) have bi-/tri-modal mass morphologies. All contours are equally spaced in the log.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225385/359-2-417-fig008.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225385\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig008.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=SHAW1eN3ZyBaFrwRtOAG3w9d0zwRQCAk-wPwPoKJJbXJSMKLFyKxRy800h0P0CgThJYnAEWGvBAFSlzDm0jNDgX2xE0cSTo4bPtFc-bOxzdXmtM0lNQ04jbXio1Jv-I1N7aQYhgBFgWRic13a-GYgc~dviEwX6QJaIdcpwgRSGsGQpf4jXVt3dS13Q94NZZ6NoHU0in2jHKqlACqQkjcfTGK6DOxmk6uoXdQAMlU1vUBrbFmciPZlL~sctZt8vhXfaxK3rGmuFd~VJ6SA1c2Xv9Bj4U8GEfr2o38jrljr7wN9mVgR3gofgq41~v5HzfoGZCvDxNkbz6s1LOWyEjH5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225385&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig008.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each cluster in the sample, we show (left) the adaptively smoothed X-ray flux contours and (right) the iso-mass contours calculated from the best-fitting lens models. The greyscales are low-resolution renderings of the <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 frame. All three of the clusters classified as relaxed (A 383, A 963 and A 1835; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>) have very regular and centrally concentrated X-ray and mass morphologies. The seven unrelaxed clusters all have irregular X-ray morphologies, and four of them (A 68, A 773, A 2218, A 2219) have bi-/tri-modal mass morphologies. All contours are equally spaced in the log.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectral analysis was performed in the 0.8\u20139 keV energy band in PI channels, thus avoiding problems connected with the poor calibration of the detector at energies below 0.8 keV. Spectra were extracted using circular regions centred on the X-ray centroid of each cluster within a radius of 2 Mpc at the cluster redshift, being careful to mask out all the strong point sources. An absorbed <span class=\"small-caps\">mekal</span> model was used, with the equivalent hydrogen column density fixed to the relative Galactic value (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dickey &amp; Lockman 1990</a>). The temperature, plasma metallicity and normalization were left as free parameters. Because of the hard energy band used in this analysis, the derived plasma temperatures are not very sensitive to the precise value of <em>N</em><sub>H</sub>. We list the temperature of each cluster derived from the total field of view [i.e. <em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub>\u2261<em>kT</em><sub>X</sub>(<em>R</em> \u2264 2 Mpc)] in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presence of a \u2018cool core\u2019 (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2001</a>) could bias low the cluster temperature measurements. As the aim is to obtain a reliable global measurement of the cluster temperatures, we therefore remeasured the temperatures in an annulus <em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub>\u2261<em>kT</em><sub>X</sub> (0.1 \u2264<em>R</em> \u2264 2 Mpc) centred on the X-ray centroid of each cluster (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch 1998</a>). There is a significant difference between <em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub> and <em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub> in just two clusters: A 383 and A 1835 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>). Both of these clusters have previously been identified as containing an emission-line BCG (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2001</a>), which is arguably the most reliable indicator of central cold material in clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Edge et al. 1990</a>). We also note that none of the eight clusters for which, within the uncertainties, <em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub> =<em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub> have previously been identified as containing a cool core (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">White, Jones &amp; Forman 1997</a>). We list the temperature ratios, <em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub>/<em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub>, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17225388\" scrollto-destination=\"17225388\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=lfTuem7PwqPC1VUVOTrXs0do5lvTARFmHVPtkgX9J15HaWVFjogcVvVR5IVye3Dwj~-RxAvXIlPOPsx386V3MlSHaGNtVLVRQMCnPtJqxT3ghjtkPNWeIhj8TkGAxUnkTpGnRiAXZ05SQC~SWHKFwZ76POrIov8E240-4mOYNfdKzRF0fIRepaPSEl~gzXCRbnd8yQTE06GIJOLPIQ9~fn7zLjlYM2ze50W8gMUsjhf~1XzxRSXvllbMnyXRsunFndkWcMimG~exvBB8Lxr-KMxtML2Mt61jM4e--Z5NOz9mE8pqWyyRjZpCyuVpGullF5c2qsKbRrmRNtldgBI0OA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass and substructure diagnostics.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225388/359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225388\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=yN0rkD02hL2QOBpsOUb~TPoB5fFW0mhEJXRNwZk~n9meIBciavr4mfUy3BqBuOCQdSafm0l~Ujna3Pj0m~-KB7q1VA1D2OolIXfar26KNWnwndzUS1SqRyGHe4T8DHeavfetrHNTyPQ3PYsGsQaB0k0G8cmVq5107rV28uL7IekhvUuINA~3foX2kVdxFJumkj03nUgWyyo2rxqW2DNhGJduuJELJp0IsmK84wulq6YdCM8UYztUawnl569AgfhB6dTwLqH1RE2SECkFBR2GEePEq9moGqRSzAp-X6h~w8vdo0764eUKtNpNeqxl88Exal31X16ImX6G5jC0mvUQ6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225388&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl006.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass and substructure diagnostics.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225389 id=\"17225389\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6 Results</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We begin with a brief review of where the preceding three sections of analysis and modelling have brought us toward our goals of characterizing the dynamical maturity of X-ray luminous clusters at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 and calibrating the high-mass end of the mass\u2013temperature relation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detailed gravitational lens models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a>) reveal the total matter content of the clusters; in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1.1</a> we compute and analyse detailed mass maps using the best-fitting models. These measurements of total cluster mass are complemented by analysis of archival X-ray data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>) which reveals the details of the hot intracluster medium. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1.2</a>, we compare the spatial distribution of total mass with the spatial structures in the X-ray flux maps and temperature measurements derived from the <em>Chandra</em> observations. We also compare the total matter and ICM with the spatial distribution of stars in the clusters using the measurements of the <em>K</em>-band luminosity of cluster galaxies estimated in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3.1</a>. In summary, the synthesis presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a> aims to diagnose whether or not the clusters are dynamically mature using independent probes of dark matter (inferred from the lensing mass maps), hot intracluster gas and cluster galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a> we adopt a different approach \u2013 we explore correlations between the integrated properties of the clusters. Specifically, we use the cluster mass, X-ray luminosity and X-ray temperature measurements to normalize the scaling relations between these quantities and to investigate the scatter about these normalizations. A key focus of this exercise is to exploit the structural results from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a> to search for structural segregation in the scaling relations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225393 id=\"17225393\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-1>6.1 Mass and structure of cluster cores</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We begin by using the gravitational lens models to measure the mass of each cluster, and to quantify the spatial distribution of that mass. All of the diagnostics discussed in this section are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>, together with the overall diagnosis of \u2018relaxed\u2019 or \u2018unrelaxed\u2019\u2013 we define these terms in this section.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225395 id=\"17225395\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-1-1>6.1.1 Total cluster mass and its spatial distribution</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We adopt a fixed projected aperture of <em>R</em> = 500 kpc which is well matched to the scales probed by the <em>HST</em> data, and measure the mass interior to that radius: <em>M</em><sub>tot</sub>\u2261<em>M</em> (<em>R</em> \u2264 500 kpc). We also want to characterize the spatial distribution of mass in the cluster core. The number of cluster-scale mass components (<em>N</em><sub>DM</sub>) in the lens models sheds some light on this question (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Tables 4</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). However, <em>N</em><sub>DM</sub> does not contain any explicit information concerning mass. We therefore complement this quantity by measuring <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>, defined as the projected mass within <em>R</em> = 500 kpc that is associated with the centrally located mass components, i.e. the dominant cluster-scale mass component and the BCG. We list the central mass fraction, <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub>, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>. The uncertainties in these measurements are estimated by exploring the parameter space occupied by each lens model, identifying the family of models that satisfy \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u2264 1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster-to-cluster differences in central mass fractions probably arise for two reasons: (i) cluster-scale mass components in the lens models that are associated with massive infalling structures and (ii) cluster galaxies that are associated both with the central cluster-scale DM halo (and are presumably virialized) and with the infalling structures. The central mass fraction therefore characterizes the dominance of the central concentration of mass in the overall cluster mass distribution. The measurements listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>) reveal that the clusters fall into two categories: A 267, A 383, A 963 and A 1835 form a homogeneous subsample, all with <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> &gt; 0.95, i.e. mass distributions heavily dominated by the central components; the remaining six all have <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> &lt; 0.95 and are much more diverse than the former subsample, with central mass fractions spanning 0.4 \u2264<em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> \u2264 0.9.</p>                        <a id=\"17225398\" scrollto-destination=\"17225398\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig009.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=kXsKlaoSDwUOqjNkV30QMAvScWiuUYY~7tvYCqqyFzd~q8jN1WwmSqA3faB6aO5at3BH7SIoYUNtZO0dAyYenYjBHPJZIahgECC56wdupY~vZ2MJLCiSw~IH082LZ0O1CxjsChnzu1waI-KOwLuR9A-c1nDwiIQpaFkJmwsO~DBapzauWhqluAgT~0JRukR4O8uZcxCyWYvCGSWsQSmCEFhthuofBlNnPOAgZ50JVi2CJsWf61IGmQghAj-UoEXEgsEdu4P1fcmZaJ3mVvPzKq8saRkyFqhQMhL2tgNTH7o1~zUbb3ZDNy~6fImp4qOMV4ogBV5LnzGb0y7N61n2UQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Central mass fraction, Mcen/Mtot versus central K-band luminosity fraction, LK,BCG/LK,tot (Section 6.1). This plot reveals a remarkably clean separation between clusters with a mass distribution that is heavily dominated by the central mass components, and a stellar luminosity distribution that is dominated by the BCG. The horizontal and vertical dashed lines mark the divisions between high and low central mass and K-band luminosity fractions, respectively. See Section 6.1.1 for further discussion of this separation.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225398/359-2-417-fig009.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig009.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=U3C5B~lAIr15vc5V6NHWMfFU7TLdoTnR3Jdimwxi117-dGv0-ccfHsLE2oEesQ1JAbxVSkWWl5dO84Spg6QzscAMebZKbnhTI2s1KS2jX4TZpx7VQU61Kev1~Qavh4726axv-d-DQHtWLkrxsmONP1EQ9VEBimeFFUEZtrdM4nQH~BQ25NcwZwP-FZ5~JFoI6Xi~MikYYnNNRjP7zuBHEfMRuQnO4MsWUzZsavcwLfHUIBKJAtX97MgjHX25ssqaGkXxys3WMZvQ7s3yGH4huuHgwtje0oVOAfMKwKeT53Jt6IggFj69rOnA4f3HtZSZwvfU7mFZKnF3e8dVe8KQjQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225398&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central mass fraction, <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> versus central <em>K</em>-band luminosity fraction, <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a>). This plot reveals a remarkably clean separation between clusters with a mass distribution that is heavily dominated by the central mass components, and a stellar luminosity distribution that is dominated by the BCG. The horizontal and vertical dashed lines mark the divisions between high and low central mass and <em>K</em>-band luminosity fractions, respectively. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1.1</a> for further discussion of this separation.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig009.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=kXsKlaoSDwUOqjNkV30QMAvScWiuUYY~7tvYCqqyFzd~q8jN1WwmSqA3faB6aO5at3BH7SIoYUNtZO0dAyYenYjBHPJZIahgECC56wdupY~vZ2MJLCiSw~IH082LZ0O1CxjsChnzu1waI-KOwLuR9A-c1nDwiIQpaFkJmwsO~DBapzauWhqluAgT~0JRukR4O8uZcxCyWYvCGSWsQSmCEFhthuofBlNnPOAgZ50JVi2CJsWf61IGmQghAj-UoEXEgsEdu4P1fcmZaJ3mVvPzKq8saRkyFqhQMhL2tgNTH7o1~zUbb3ZDNy~6fImp4qOMV4ogBV5LnzGb0y7N61n2UQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Central mass fraction, Mcen/Mtot versus central K-band luminosity fraction, LK,BCG/LK,tot (Section 6.1). This plot reveals a remarkably clean separation between clusters with a mass distribution that is heavily dominated by the central mass components, and a stellar luminosity distribution that is dominated by the BCG. The horizontal and vertical dashed lines mark the divisions between high and low central mass and K-band luminosity fractions, respectively. See Section 6.1.1 for further discussion of this separation.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225398/359-2-417-fig009.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig009.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=U3C5B~lAIr15vc5V6NHWMfFU7TLdoTnR3Jdimwxi117-dGv0-ccfHsLE2oEesQ1JAbxVSkWWl5dO84Spg6QzscAMebZKbnhTI2s1KS2jX4TZpx7VQU61Kev1~Qavh4726axv-d-DQHtWLkrxsmONP1EQ9VEBimeFFUEZtrdM4nQH~BQ25NcwZwP-FZ5~JFoI6Xi~MikYYnNNRjP7zuBHEfMRuQnO4MsWUzZsavcwLfHUIBKJAtX97MgjHX25ssqaGkXxys3WMZvQ7s3yGH4huuHgwtje0oVOAfMKwKeT53Jt6IggFj69rOnA4f3HtZSZwvfU7mFZKnF3e8dVe8KQjQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225398&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig009.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central mass fraction, <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> versus central <em>K</em>-band luminosity fraction, <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a>). This plot reveals a remarkably clean separation between clusters with a mass distribution that is heavily dominated by the central mass components, and a stellar luminosity distribution that is dominated by the BCG. The horizontal and vertical dashed lines mark the divisions between high and low central mass and <em>K</em>-band luminosity fractions, respectively. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1.1</a> for further discussion of this separation.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As an independent cross-check on this subclassification of the clusters, we measure the distribution of stars in the clusters using the <em>K</em>-band luminosities of cluster galaxies described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.3.1</a>. We divide the <em>K</em>-band luminosity of each BCG (i.e. the luminosity that is spatially coincident with the central mass components) by the combined <em>K</em>-band luminosity of all the cluster galaxies detected in each <em>HST</em> frame. These central <em>K</em>-band luminosity fractions (<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub>) are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> and plotted versus the central mass fractions in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>. The central luminosity fractions span <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub>\u223c 0.2\u20130.8, and are not obviously more homogeneous for low and high central fraction clusters. Nevertheless, there appears to be a roughly monotonic relationship between the central mass fraction and central <em>K</em>-band luminosity fraction, thus to first order confirming the separation of the cluster sample into two structural classes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This subclassification into a relatively homogeneous subsample of clusters with <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> &gt; 0.95 and a diverse subsample with 0.4 \u2264<em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> \u2264 0.9 matches the details of the cluster lens models reasonably well. The lens model of each of the former clusters contains a single cluster-scale mass component. The situation is less clear-cut for the latter subsample. Lens models of four of the six clusters contain two or more cluster-scale mass components, i.e. their mass distributions are unambiguously bi- or tri-modal (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>), and thus the low central mass fractions are dominated by substructure in the cluster cores. However, the remaining two (A 209 and A 1763) contain a single cluster-scale mass component. It is therefore ambiguous whether the moderately low central mass fractions in these clusters genuinely reflect cluster substructure, or are simply due to the cluster galaxy populations. One possibility is that these two clusters are both undergoing mergers in the plane of the sky. This would help to explain the absence of an obvious strong-lensing signal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>) and the low aperture mass measurements (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>) relative to the other clusters. In such a scenario the mass associated with the secondary mass clump could presumably lie outside of the WFPC2 field of view, therefore reducing the cross-section to lensing and the fixed aperture mass of the cluster relative to a viewing angle more closely aligned with the merger axis. Wide-field weak-lensing analysis would help to resolve this uncertainty.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225401 id=\"17225401\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-1-2>6.1.2 Total mass versus X-ray flux and temperature</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now compare the cluster mass distributions with the X-ray observations to gain further leverage in diagnosing the maturity of the full sample of 10 clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Iso-mass contours computed from the best-fitting lens models and adaptively smoothed X-ray flux contours from the <em>Chandra</em> observations are overplotted on the <em>HST</em> frames in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>. We also carefully check the pointing accuracy of the <em>Chandra</em> observations using 28 \u00d7 42 arcmin<sup>2</sup> panoramic CFH12k imaging of these cluster fields (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Czoske 2002</a>). X-ray point sources are located in the <em>Chandra</em> frames and cross-identified in the CFH12k frames to confirm that the <em>Chandra</em> astrometry matches the frame defined by the optical data to an rms accuracy of \u22642 kpc at the cluster redshift. We measured the offset between the position of the X-ray peak in each <em>Chandra</em> frame and list \u0394<em>r</em><sub>peak</sub>, the offset between this position and the centre of mass in the mass maps in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>. We compare the mass and X-ray morphologies with the mass and luminosity fractions discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1.1</a> Three of the four high central mass fraction clusters (A 383, A 963, A 1835) appear relaxed at X-ray wavelengths, i.e. with a circular or mildly elliptical morphology. A 267, is an exception to this picture \u2013 its X-ray flux contours are much less regular than the other three systems, and there appears to be a large offset between X-ray and mass centres. The six low central mass fraction clusters also have irregular X-ray morphologies and misalignment between X-ray and mass peaks.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also list in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> the ratio of the total to annular temperatures (<em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub>/<em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub>) of each cluster measured in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a> to test for the presence of cool cores. Eight of the clusters, comprising the six with low central mass fractions plus A 267 and A 963 display no evidence of a cool core. The absence of evidence for a cool core in A 267 is unsurprising given the likely dynamical disturbance in the cluster core as indicated by its X-ray morphology. A temperature ratio of unity for A 963 is also consistent with previous work on this cluster, which has traditionally been classified as an \u2018intermediate\u2019 cluster (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1998</a>), i.e. it appears to be quite relaxed, but has not acquired a cool core since (presumed) previous merger activity. This is also consistent with the mild ellipticity in the X-ray isophotes, in contrast to the almost circular isophotes of A 383 and A 1835.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225405 id=\"17225405\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-1-3>6.1.3 Summary</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> lists all of the diagnostics described in this section. Each diagnostic in isolation offers a slightly different view of the dynamical maturity of each cluster. We combine all of the available information to determine a robust diagnosis of the maturity of each cluster, and to identify the remaining uncertainties. In making the overall classifications listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>, we define the term \u2018relaxed\u2019 to mean that the cluster is dynamically mature in all diagnostics available to us, with the exception that we do not require it to have a cool core (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">McCarthy et al. 2004</a> for a discussion of relaxed clusters that do not host a cool core). In terms of the diagnostics listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>, this means that <em>N</em><sub>DM</sub> = 1, <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> \u2265 0.95, <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub> \u2265 0.5, \u0394<em>r</em><sub>peak</sub> &lt; 4 kpc, and the X-ray morphology is either circular or mildly elliptical. We also note that the X-ray flux contours appear to be more circular than the iso-mass contours in the relaxed clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>), as would be expected if these clusters are in hydrostatic equilibrium. The unrelaxed clusters do not satisfy one or more of the criteria that define the relaxed clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We therefore conclude that seven out of the 10 clusters in our study, i.e. 70 \u00b1 20 per cent of X-ray luminous cluster cores at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 are dynamically immature (the error bar assumes binomial statistics; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gehrels 1986</a>). Henceforth we classify A 383, A 963 and A 1835 as \u2018relaxed\u2019 clusters and A 68, A 209, A 267, A 773, A 1763, A 2218 and A 2219 as \u2018unrelaxed\u2019 clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225408 id=\"17225408\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-2>6.2 Cluster scaling relations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now investigate the scaling relations between cluster mass, temperature and X-ray luminosity, focusing on the normalization of and scatter around the relations and the impact of the dynamical immaturity of 70 per cent of the sample identified in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225410 id=\"17225410\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-2-1>6.2.1 Mass versus X-ray luminosity</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The sample is selected on X-ray luminosity (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>), we therefore begin with the mass\u2013luminosity relation. First, we explore whether we can improve on the precision of the <em>ROSAT</em>-based X-ray luminosities (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>) using the <em>Chandra</em> data. One of the largest uncertainties in the luminosities quoted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a> is that the large PSF of <em>ROSAT</em> limited the efficiency with which point sources could be excised from the cluster data. The sub-arcsecond PSF of the <em>Chandra</em> data overcomes this problem; however, we find that the corrections for point sources are modest and comparable with the extrapolation uncertainties that arise from the field of view of <em>Chandra</em>, which is too small to embrace all of the extended emission from clusters at <em>z</em> = 0.2. The <em>Chandra</em>-based luminosities are therefore no more precise than the <em>ROSAT</em> luminosities at this redshift. We therefore adopt the X-ray luminosities upon which the sample was selected (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We plot <em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> versus X-ray luminosity in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>. Despite selecting very X-ray luminous clusters for this study (<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 0.1\u20132.4 keV), these data span a sufficient dynamic range, in principle, to constrain both the slope and the normalization of the mass\u2013luminosity relation (cf. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Finoguenov, Reiprich &amp; B\u00f6hringer 2001</a>). We parametrize the mass\u2013luminosity relation as follows:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq001.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq001.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=xE1WM6k41cy-rfobnYDqwQSfsC6-4avT7RZA9sDaI2r5dKFFpeq1wZDmvZeq5hjQVYBaMYBr7oVmALLLR-KIVUHVI54XWR0TQobOhCBqtBts-YntQLVpnm4eDdx8oaFCVAbGim7ti0isVC3nY5hx~i7ji8OKxEG2eTAFq7INr3jROaWwN-nNQKJPYWI9imgBOjYpZ8vDD5cBtr-86qlxNXlRwDrZ80c2P26IgYrf8mx6waTLYlRhEBhDtuyhv2CTW-ItvDc5Fi074W16Qxr3mlcWTM7bg6Y5TJnGI7fzJ1DSMq5DcIx6gepsZ0XeT79Z4mCfXK6fwlk3~BriT97Wuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq001.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div> and try to solve for <em>A</em> and \u03b1 following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Akritas &amp; Bershady (1996)</a> to account for errors in both variables and unknown intrinsic scatter. Unsurprisingly, given the large scatter that is immediately obvious upon visual inspection of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>, this exercise fails. We therefore fix the slope parameter and simply measure the normalization, <em>A</em>. This is achieved by computing the mean mass and luminosity, and then solving log <em>A</em> =\u3008log(<em>L</em><sub>X</sub>)\u3009\u2212\u3008log(<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub>)\u3009/\u03b1. Uncertainties in both mass and luminosity are included in the calculation by repeating it 10<sup>4</sup> times, on each occasion drawing values of <em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> randomly from the distributions defined by the error bars on X-ray luminosity and mass listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Tables 1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, respectively. Simple gravitational collapse models predict that \u03b1= 0.75 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser 1986</a>), we therefore initially measure the normalization using this value for the slope, and also compute the intrinsic scatter around this model. These calculations are performed for the whole sample of 10 clusters and the relaxed and unrelaxed subsamples, and the results listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>. Based on these calculations, there is no evidence for segregation between relaxed and unrelaxed clusters in the mass\u2013luminosity plane, and the scatter is \u03c3<sub><em>M</em></sub>\u2243 0.4.</div>                        <a id=\"17225414\" scrollto-destination=\"17225414\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig010.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=yHZuBqGAy~9yuROQEgNG1q9xqCR1z~NfcLMuud95Qc7UjpjM8eAA2BZYZTXSsrRefmUTBrBFAP~ENNcwBXk1AWL0dkGXoDBoe-AARzsOcXcTBsqANVEqj5cohJ2SpfJOZCz4AsXeJMzWcY2q3lkdwmcT~9ueBKbUn9Npp7~No7IK2IcLEDoS-wWQ86gFNibn2ehq8vQcxENaBUJdLg35DshL4yHoAz1McAzJucN7dI5qDM9MOaeqW1fXm8naxJIXq2vqyDNoC8iH2b85UAJb03zyJQWpH2RdvqPLYVsm2iype8B4TVkVsqu0DuSfs8bPos6GlaVB5j9eCtX4JxhqtQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass\u2013luminosity (left), mass\u2013temperature (centre) and luminosity\u2013temperature (right) relations for our sample of 10 clusters. The relaxed/unrelaxed clusters are shown by the circular/square symbols as explained in the legend. The error bars on some points are so small that they are smaller than the symbols. The solid and dashed lines show the best-fitting relations normalized by the relaxed and unrelaxed clusters, respectively; see Section 6.2 and Table 7 for further information. The error bars on each line show the uncertainty on the normalization of each relation. In summary, these relations show that the large scatter detected in the mass\u2013luminosity plane appears to be symmetric; in both the mass\u2013temperature and luminosity\u2013temperature planes, the scatter appears to be asymmetric, with the unrelaxed clusters being on average hotter than the relaxed clusters. This segregation is statistically insignificant in the luminosity\u2013temperature plane, and significant at the 2\u20133\u03c3 level in the mass\u2013temperature plane. The dotted line on the mass\u2013luminosity and luminosity\u2013temperature plots shows the selection function of LX \u2265 8 \u00d7 1044 erg s\u22121 (0.1\u20132.4 keV) (Section 2).\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig010.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225414/359-2-417-fig010.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig010.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig010.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=u31Ffac0OBkOEkbnwf33y4lzmGaXQHih2msNx4SQ77juMl75xigczESR2zAJgzt4G8A3T7mn~E9I1IJzCCkj6UxbAs8E1yOGBaANujrQrvPQnnbiPgIPojJUrGJSgdQIGePE8M1l0vC15sbCcf2KV3RGoZ6JzqD61MmSTQT9vLvdYQUZ2XXzovlwUo0yeWO~EISkDgpz7KeN0yvApYqCzZJ5rqnEcvRxoLJXCZVibodwcwUfJJAc96c70img0aILyHPeFUbkaGfck84n5Vam3PKgDG42UNm0H0Xx31rLZLhrTI1yeqjS-P1QHUfAvOyxpv18MTEbRLqNqbIIKFoDZg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225414&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig010.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass\u2013luminosity (left), mass\u2013temperature (centre) and luminosity\u2013temperature (right) relations for our sample of 10 clusters. The relaxed/unrelaxed clusters are shown by the circular/square symbols as explained in the legend. The error bars on some points are so small that they are smaller than the symbols. The solid and dashed lines show the best-fitting relations normalized by the relaxed and unrelaxed clusters, respectively; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a> for further information. The error bars on each line show the uncertainty on the normalization of each relation. In summary, these relations show that the large scatter detected in the mass\u2013luminosity plane appears to be symmetric; in both the mass\u2013temperature and luminosity\u2013temperature planes, the scatter appears to be asymmetric, with the unrelaxed clusters being on average hotter than the relaxed clusters. This segregation is statistically insignificant in the luminosity\u2013temperature plane, and significant at the 2\u20133\u03c3 level in the mass\u2013temperature plane. The dotted line on the mass\u2013luminosity and luminosity\u2013temperature plots shows the selection function of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4 keV) (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig010.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=yHZuBqGAy~9yuROQEgNG1q9xqCR1z~NfcLMuud95Qc7UjpjM8eAA2BZYZTXSsrRefmUTBrBFAP~ENNcwBXk1AWL0dkGXoDBoe-AARzsOcXcTBsqANVEqj5cohJ2SpfJOZCz4AsXeJMzWcY2q3lkdwmcT~9ueBKbUn9Npp7~No7IK2IcLEDoS-wWQ86gFNibn2ehq8vQcxENaBUJdLg35DshL4yHoAz1McAzJucN7dI5qDM9MOaeqW1fXm8naxJIXq2vqyDNoC8iH2b85UAJb03zyJQWpH2RdvqPLYVsm2iype8B4TVkVsqu0DuSfs8bPos6GlaVB5j9eCtX4JxhqtQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass\u2013luminosity (left), mass\u2013temperature (centre) and luminosity\u2013temperature (right) relations for our sample of 10 clusters. The relaxed/unrelaxed clusters are shown by the circular/square symbols as explained in the legend. The error bars on some points are so small that they are smaller than the symbols. The solid and dashed lines show the best-fitting relations normalized by the relaxed and unrelaxed clusters, respectively; see Section 6.2 and Table 7 for further information. The error bars on each line show the uncertainty on the normalization of each relation. In summary, these relations show that the large scatter detected in the mass\u2013luminosity plane appears to be symmetric; in both the mass\u2013temperature and luminosity\u2013temperature planes, the scatter appears to be asymmetric, with the unrelaxed clusters being on average hotter than the relaxed clusters. The relaxed/unrelaxed clusters are shown by the circular/square symbols as explained in the legend. The error bars on some points are so small that they are smaller than the symbols. The solid and dashed lines show the best-fitting relations normalized by the relaxed and unrelaxed clusters, respectively; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a> for further information. In summary, these relations show that the large scatter detected in the mass\u2013luminosity plane appears to be symmetric; in both the mass\u2013temperature and luminosity\u2013temperature planes, the scatter appears to be asymmetric, with the unrelaxed clusters being on average hotter than the relaxed clusters. The dotted line on the mass\u2013luminosity and luminosity\u2013temperature plots shows the selection function of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4 keV) (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>).</p></div></div>                        <a alt=\"Scaling relations \u2013 normalizations and scatters.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225415/359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225415\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Scaling relations \u2013 normalizations and scatters.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"tbl7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Table 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=n2U3LNP90c~E8IJH~zglU0iakz0C7~8hbc72i7sTjLrsXAfq3tzL9JXbs8xDiORAJEVk796LbafB-fxNPbFkQ5oo8mBQ4IoVQsFzGR7vwpqWPndjBYr6zHH9zkL7B~f90hfBDUQ7Ff5KtZlPxz9sa-EIQ4TLNQIgu4V2w6wxdQBL1nSklBC~2ZT0bo7sqSbyHkbQqyx0R79k8ULG34k6UNhVVsuSa8jzGtTnF2LFBOh2DW8h3Ti2IvTGyhhRzSNBDkI4DytOCG5H8qeZscPghh9QoceKqCIKf0ZCB4tlOI2bbN05u6z6WxBuGSki4Fs92AQdbHjo51rf3qHhi5DPGw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Scaling relations \u2013 normalizations and scatters.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225415/359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225415\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&Signature=a~CuwFBGFnafCs1EEb7Ix~kiiUJ77h0-1NDrDmILjA3xi6GfClrDyBWt9yXoHJ-MbWjaEW9ZD~-8WqwdQS6w~uZyHTHUkUHGv-fOGpocU-tw7XQrXMbGtR2myV1tYBzHpWODLRmNYcN5aDruyl4WmGjB8k004vOEI8OpG1OnG3Wk~tCoiukJnDK27T9bwvV6Jx3cv41hR9ObGTThPKnayAm6KdtGx2HbxNukb7XA2TNr4g1JuQpSj71HBnduNATMwygaKARMHs5Q6Oo9~atb6f~PXDyAmHFUmlTo0G60MRAZrz9tMgqN7yKJmfp5vjCNRgVMz4kA8SYgFCnBYyD0tQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225415&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-tbl007.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Scaling relations \u2013 normalizations and scatters.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We repeat these calculations using an empirical determination of the slope: \u03b1= 0.76<sup>+0.16</sup><sub>\u22120.13</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2003</a>), drawing randomly from the error distribution on \u03b1 in the same manner as described above for the mass and luminosity data. This has the effect of broadening the uncertainties on the normalizations listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>, but does not change the overall conclusion. We also repeat the calculations after applying the possible 12 per cent upward correction to the weak-lensing-based mass measurements discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2</a> (i.e. A 209, A 267, A 773, A 1763 and A 1835). The results are insensitive to this correction.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225417 id=\"17225417\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-2-2>6.2.2 Mass versus temperature</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We plot <em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> versus <em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>, and parametrize the relation as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq002.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq002.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=a9mxAQjkkkKR~z3PqYbhIqNCSizV79DPSzdHxtqvN95tWdEF~VLD3p5Cr-gjhV0pb7aFCpLDycb4-1RC5ByWrQQ6kirlVLU~ddkZQ6RzcagvW~5RkIKwdn2kHN575OV91rayTJwrBTHhAi0iIGzuwsLR3Fs6S~jH8-V-1TpAu~YQTVLsAiGCxvDktE5UlQ1p3MRwc72DkF1KjBGodSFTZQjLdfIo2G~E7qDwXGVSRGkMs4MExD3RXvfX5rC7HqM1fx0mTTaHtiSZzsJVOim70x1~mIAXoPzMPS2JuXoaAklq0AoF7wInlmj9M~SnzGjdTFGjt4nx89Eur1KdYV2mXQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq002.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div> Note that we consider <em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub>, and not <em>kT</em><sub>X,tot</sub>; the results described here are therefore robust to the presence of cool cores in relaxed clusters.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We adopt the theoretically predicted slope: \u03b2= 1.5, which is consistent with observations for the most massive clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Finoguenov et al. 2001</a>). Following the procedures described above, we measure the normalization and scatter, and list the results in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>. Two significant results emerge: (i) the unrelaxed clusters are on average 40 per cent hotter than the relaxed clusters at 3\u03c3 significance and (ii) the scatter about the mass\u2013temperature relation for all clusters is \u03c3<sub><em>T</em></sub>\u2243 0.4. The statistical significance of the temperature off-set is reduced to 2.5\u03c3 if an empirically measured value of \u03b2 is used in place of the theoretical value (e.g. \u03b2= 1.58<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.07</sub>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Finoguenov et al. 2001</a>). Note that, as in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2.1</a>, these results are insensitive to the possible 12 per cent systematic uncertainty in the mass of the weak-shear constrained clusters.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225420 id=\"17225420\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6-2-3>6.2.3 X-ray luminosity versus temperature</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Finally, we parametrize the luminosity\u2013temperature relation as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq003.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq003.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=qeS3o2dBqrPf85RxvTSMr9Xr9Cu4f-E1nxKipcnzOOWRn~~GVLZ~8FYMlZaGNLdOkHH5uKyWan1iePlInNVY2yRJT5XVuno65fIUChKwK1mUqpvrzmLEUrZODzHh11hSCC-n8gDxzScOT6DaPPOzuh3w9kYeqk3a5Yi-BtTzw-3VaFUfqUSM1zhRRY050KmaRbKQK6rnMHZYRantv4nbVDcJEhqoo3jrd8Chgt8VS8YlsiZxOj3NWLx6ubztC-yx4QaUJhrmxBipHMuCalW9NavcM8URv2wZEk407haWHyCFM96bwcOo9zphXxNxse0HPfLOvbzRhO247yB~wyavVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq003.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div> and repeat the analysis described above. Adopting the theoretical value of \u03b3= 2, the measured values of <em>C</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>) indicate that unrelaxed clusters are 30 per cent hotter than relaxed clusters, at 2.4\u03c3 significance, i.e. less significance than in the mass\u2013temperature plane. However, adopting an empirical measurement of \u03b3 in the fit (\u03b3= 2.09 \u00b1 0.29; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch 1998</a>) eliminates the statistical significance in this difference. Nevertheless, this hint of structural segregation in the luminosity\u2013temperature plane (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>) is significant for two reasons. First, it provides a lensing-independent cross-check on the results in the mass\u2013temperature plane, in that both luminosity and temperature measurements are independent of the lens modelling upon which the cluster mass measurements are based. Secondly, it is consistent with previous detections of structural segregation in the luminosity\u2013temperature plane (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fabian et al. 1994</a>).</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225422 id=\"17225422\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7>7 Discussion</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have combined a detailed, high-resolution strong-lensing analysis of an objectively selected cluster sample with analysis of a high-resolution X-ray spectro-imaging data set. As such, it affords the first opportunity to combine high-quality optical and X-ray probes of cluster mass, structure and thermodynamics. The results presented in the previous section may be summarized as follows.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><span class=\"label\">(i)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">70 \u00b1 20 per cent of X-ray luminous cluster cores at <em>z</em> = 0.2 are dynamically immature;</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(ii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">scaling relations between cluster mass, luminosity and temperature display scatter of \u03c3\u223c 0.3\u20130.6;</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(iii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">the normalization of the mass\u2013temperature relation for unrelaxed (dynamically immature) clusters is 40 per cent hotter than for relaxed clusters.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We discuss these results in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss7-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Sections 7.1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss7-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7.2</a>, and close by considering the implications of the results for the use of massive clusters as cosmological probes (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss7-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 7.3</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225427 id=\"17225427\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7-1>7.1 Dynamical immaturity of cluster cores</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy clusters grow by accreting DM, gas and galaxies from their surroundings, including the filamentary structure (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss1\"></span><a href=\"#ss1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 1</a>). The observed structure of clusters therefore probes a combination of both the infall history and the relaxation processes that govern the time-scales on which clusters regain equilibrium following cluster\u2013cluster mergers.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The clusters can be grouped into three categories on the basis of the multiwavelength diagnostics listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6</a>. The least ambiguous category is the relaxed clusters (A 383, A 963 and A 1835 \u2013 see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.1</a>), all of which display a similar degree of relaxation in both mass and X-ray. The other two categories are subdivisions of the unrelaxed clusters. First, we consider the four unrelaxed clusters with obviously bi-/tri-modal mass distributions (A 68, A 773, A 2218 and A 2219). Whilst the X-ray flux contours of these clusters are both irregular and elongated in the same directions as the mass distributions, there is no obvious evidence of bi-modality in the X-ray flux. On radial scales greater than a few tens of kpc from the centre of the cluster BCGs, the mass maps should trace the distribution of DM. The ICM in these clusters therefore appears to be more relaxed than the DM distribution. DM is generally believed to be collisionless (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Davis et al. 1985</a>; however, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spergel &amp; Steinhardt 2000</a> for an alternative hypothesis); in contrast, the ICM is baryonic and therefore collisional. If these clusters are assumed to be relaxing after the initial encounter between two pre-merger systems, then the absence of X-ray multimodality in clusters with mass multimodality would qualitatively support the collisionless DM hypothesis. On the other hand, if these clusters are observed immediately before the initial encounter, then the absence of X-ray multimodality would likely not indicate any difference between the relaxation time-scales of baryons and DM. Firm conclusions in this area await a thorough investigation of possible biases introduced by the adoption of a cluster selection function based on X-ray luminosity, and detailed comparison of empirical results with synthetic clusters extracted from numerical simulations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The third category comprises the remaining three unrelaxed clusters (A 209, A 267 and A 1763) for which there is no compelling evidence in the current data for multimodality in the DM distribution. Nevertheless, several clues as to the true DM distributions are present in the data. For example, the strongly elliptical mass distribution of A 267 may indicate that the matter distribution is more complex than a single elongated DM halo plus cluster galaxy population (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Edge et al. 2003</a>). Deep wide-field weak-lensing analysis is needed to explore this possibility, specifically to search for evidence of other mass concentrations using weak gravitational lensing (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2003</a>). Turning to A 1763, galaxies appear to be falling into this cluster along a \u223c2-Mpc long filament (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vall\u00e9e &amp; Bridle 1982</a>; Bardeau et al., in preparation). This cluster may therefore be experiencing a merger in the plane of the sky, which is thus poorly sampled by the small field of view of the WFPC2 data used in this study. An alternative interpretation of these three clusters is that sufficient time has elapsed since the presumed merger event for the DM distribution to relax and thus not present a bi-/tri-modal structure at the epoch of observation. However, given the strong dynamical disturbance evident from the X-ray flux maps, we consider this unlikely.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Numerical simulations from several groups suggest that both gas dynamics and substructure in the DM distribution may persist for as long as \u223c5 Gyr following a merger event (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schindler &amp; Mueller 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nakamura, Hattori &amp; Mineshige 1995</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Roettiger, Loken &amp; Burns 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tormen, Diaferio &amp; Syer 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">De Lucia et al. 2004</a>). This implies that despite the expected differences between the physics of the ICM and the DM, the relaxation time-scales for these two matter components may be comparable. The differences in cluster X-ray and mass morphologies noted above imply that the X-ray and mass morphological evolution of clusters may follow different evolutionary paths, even if the overall relaxation time-scales are indeed comparable. This idea is supported by the numerical simulations of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ricker &amp; Sarazin (2001)</a>, who found that oscillations in the gravitational potential of a merging cluster (due to the dominant collisionless DM) sustain turbulence and thus non-relaxation of the ICM on time-scales comparable with that required for the DM to achieve equilibrium.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From an observational stand-point, next steps toward constraining the relevant relaxation time-scales and processes include: (i) wide-field imaging to overcome uncertainties arising from the current pencil-beam WFPC2 observations of the cluster cores; (ii) enlargement of the sample to overcome the small number statistics of comparing subsamples of approximately three systems; (iii) a detailed space-based and wide-field study of similarly selected samples of clusters at higher redshifts; and (iv) analysis of uniformly deep X-ray data to constrain the temperature structure of the unrelaxed clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we note that some previous attempts to diagnose the structural maturity of cluster cores have compared lensing-based mass measurements with mass estimates derived from X-ray data. In summary, those clusters for which lensing and X-ray masses agree have been classified as relaxed clusters, and those in disagreement as unrelaxed clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1998</a>). In this study, we have employed a broader suite of diagnostics, motivated by the high-quality space-based data available to us. We have also used each data set for the purposes for which they are best suited in an attempt to minimize the number of assumptions in our analysis; for example, we have measured the cluster mass using the gravitational lensing signal, and not X-ray data. Having said that, A 383 provides an interesting case study. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2001)</a> measured the total mass of this cluster on the scales probed by the giant gravitational arc (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>), finding reasonable agreement between lensing- and X-ray-based methods: <em>M</em><sub>lensing</sub>(&lt;65 kpc) = (3.5 \u00b1 0.1) \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>X-ray</sub>(&lt;65 kpc) = (4.0<sup>+1.1</sup><sub>\u22121.7</sub>) \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, where the X-ray mass assumes a cluster temperature of (7 \u00b1 2) keV. Following the same method as Smith et al., we find that the new <em>Chandra</em>-based temperature measurement of <em>kT</em><sub>X,ann</sub> = (5.2 \u00b1 0.2) keV (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>) yields an X-ray mass estimate of <em>M</em><sub>X-ray</sub>(&lt;65 kpc) = (3.0<sup>+0.1</sup><sub>\u22120.2</sub>) \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. We also recompute the lensing mass, finding a value of <em>M</em><sub>lensing</sub>(&lt;65 kpc) = (3.4 \u00b1 0.1) \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This is consistent with <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2001)</a>, but slightly lower due to the improved redshift information available for the gravitational arcs in this cluster (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix B</a>). The apparent improvement in precision of the X-ray mass measurement now that <em>Chandra</em> data are included in the analysis therefore suggests an X-ray/lensing mass discrepancy in this relaxed cluster at the \u223c15 per cent level. This is intriguing because, at face value, it implies that X-ray mass estimates for relaxed clusters may not be in close agreement with lensing-based mass measurements as previously claimed. A full investigation of the differences between X-ray and lensing mass measurements is beyond the scope of this study. We will return to this issue in a future article.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225434 id=\"17225434\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7-2>7.2 Cluster scaling relations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Numerous observational and theoretical studies of cluster scaling relationships have addressed the slope, normalization and intrinsic scatter of these relations (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Voit 2004</a> for a recent review). Structural segregation in the scaling relation planes has also been discussed in the context of cooling-flow and non-cooling-flow clusters in the luminosity\u2013temperature plane (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fabian et al. 1994</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen &amp; Fabian 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Markevitch 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Arnaud &amp; Evrard 1999</a>). Lensing-based mass estimates have been used to supplement X-ray cluster studies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2003</a>); however, these studies have relied on weak-lensing data without an absolute mass normalization that would come from well-defined strong-lensing constraints. The resulting large error bars in such analyses therefore degrade the advantage of using lensing as a probe of cluster mass. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1997)</a> included lensing in cluster scaling relation studies, using the weak-shear signal of optically selected clusters as a surrogate for mass to construct a shear\u2013<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> relation. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hjorth, Oukbir &amp; van Kampen (1998)</a> went a step further, using weak-lensing mass estimates to estimate the mass of eight clusters, and thus construct the first lensing-based mass\u2013temperature relation. However, as these authors point out, their use of weak-lensing and heterogeneous selection function undermines the precision of their work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The important feature of our study is that the lensing-based mass measurements are based on detailed strong-lensing mass models, the normalization of which are locked down by spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image systems and cross-calibration between strong- and weak-lensing constrained clusters. Combining the lensing results with high-quality X-ray spectro-imaging with <em>Chandra</em> places us in a hitherto unique position to explore the mass\u2013temperature plane. We therefore concentrate our discussion of cluster scaling relations in this area. It is also important to note that the mass information extracted from the lensing mass maps is two-dimensional. In contrast, the information extracted from theoretical simulations is three-dimensional. Reliable calibrations between two- and three-dimensional cluster masses have not yet been achieved. We therefore concentrate on discussing the scatter in the mass\u2013temperature plane and the related issue of structural segregation, i.e. the <em>relative</em> normalization of relaxed and unrelaxed clusters.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225437 id=\"17225437\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7-2-1>7.2.1 Scatter</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evrard, Metzler &amp; Navarro (1996)</a> predicted that solely a broad-beam measurement of the temperature of ICM in an individual cluster can be used to measure cluster masses to an rms precision of \u223c10\u201320 per cent. This is in stark contrast to the \u03c3<sub><em>M</em></sub>\u2243 0.6 scatter in mass that we detect in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a>.
