An important clue as to the origin of this difference is that the observational scatter appears to be dominated by the unrelaxed clusters (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>). However, several other factors may also contribute to both the size of the observed scatter and the apparent discrepancy between observation and theory.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We first consider the issue of aperture size. The observational mass measurements sample just the central <em>R</em> \u2264 500 kpc of each cluster; this aperture matches approximately the radius at which the cluster density is \u223c2500\u20135000 times the critical density for closure of the Universe. The scatter may therefore be dominated by systematics relevant only to the very central regions of the clusters. We use the ground-based weak-lensing analysis of the same clusters by Bardeau et al. (in preparation) to make a preliminary estimate of how the scatter may reduce if the current analysis were extended to larger radii where the cluster density is approximately 500 times the critical density. The uncertainties on Bardeau et al.'s results are large due to the poor spatial resolution of ground-based data relative to our <em>HST</em> data. However, preliminary comparison of the two data sets suggests that one-third of the scatter may be due to the small aperture size employed in this study. This variation in scatter as a function of overdensity is consistent with recent X-ray results (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori, De Grandi &amp; Molendi 2002</a>). Therefore, after taking account of aperture size, the scatter remains a factor of \u223c3 larger than the simulations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A further potentially important issue is that of selection effects. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ricker &amp; Sarazin's</a> (2001; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ritchie &amp; Thomas 2002</a>) simulations suggest that cluster\u2013cluster mergers boost cluster X-ray luminosities on time-scales of a few Gyrs. This may cause our X-ray selected sample to be biased toward merging systems. However, clusters hosting cool cores (e.g. A 1835, the most luminous cluster in our sample) are also overluminous at X-ray wavelengths relative to relaxed non-cool-core clusters. Our sample may therefore also contain a disproportionately high fraction of relaxed cool-core clusters. The details of cluster selection are a complicated subject, and it is possible that our results may not be representative of a genuinely mass-selected sample. As discussed above, a careful comparison between synthetic (i.e. numerically simulated) and observational cluster data sets and expansion of this study to a large, statistically complete sample can help to clarify this issue.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225441 id=\"17225441\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7-2-2>7.2.2 Structural segregation</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6.2</a> we found that unrelaxed clusters are 40 per cent hotter than relaxed clusters at 2.5\u03c3 significance. Clearly, the aperture size issue noted above also impacts on this result, and a wide-field weak-lensing analysis of a statistically complete sample is critical to a thorough investigation of this uncertainty. Nevertheless, the comparison with Bardeau et al.'s (in preparation) ground-based weak-lensing results provides preliminary reassurance that a substantial fraction of the 40 per cent temperature offset is a genuine physical effect.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Indeed, recent observational and theoretical work supports the idea that unrelaxed clusters are hotter than relaxed systems. Using spatially resolved spectroscopy with <em>BeppoSAX</em>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori et al. (2002)</a> claimed the normalization of the mass\u2013temperature relation of \u2018non-cooling flow\u2019 clusters to be hotter than that of \u2018cooling flow\u2019 clusters; however, Ettori et al.'s result appears to be statistically insignificant. On the theoretical side, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ricker &amp; Sarazin's (2001)</a> simulations of cluster\u2013cluster mergers indicate that merger-induced boosts of up to a factor of 10 (the amplitude of the boost depends on the mass ratio between the merging clusters and the impact parameter of the collision) in temperature can occur on short time-scales (\u22641 Gyr) due to shock-heating of the gas in a major merger. This relatively brief temperature boost suggests that not many clusters in our sample should have temperatures \u22653 times higher than the mean relation. This is indeed the case, with A 2219 being the possible sole example of a cluster currently experiencing a temperature boost of this magnitude. This cluster has previously been identified as having recently experienced a core-penetrating merger (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1995a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Giovannini, Tordi &amp; Feretti 1999</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite the short-lived extreme temperature boosts, merger remnants appear to asymptote to temperatures \u223c10\u201340 per cent higher than the pre-merger configuration, with the precise long-term boost again depending on the mass ratio and impact geometry. Assuming that elimination of aperture size and related issues (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss7-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 7.2.1</a>) reduces the temperature offset between relaxed and unrelaxed clusters to \u223c20\u201330 per cent, these theoretical results support the idea that the cluster mergers are responsible for the structural segregation of clusters in the mass\u2013temperature plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If empirically clusters are either relaxed hosts of cool cores or unrelaxed (i.e. merging or merger remnant) systems without cool cores, then merger boosts may be sufficient to explain the structural segregation. However, deep integrations with <em>Chandra</em> and <em>XMM\u2013Newton</em> indicate that the picture may not be so clear-cut. For example, some cool core clusters appear to be undergoing merger activity (e.g. Perseus; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Churazov et al. 2003</a>), and some dynamically relaxed clusters do not host a cool core (e.g. A 963 in this work). The significance of merging cool core clusters and relaxed non-cool core clusters for the merger-boost interpretation of structural segregation in the mass\u2013temperature plane is unclear at this time. For example, the mass ratio of the Perseus merger may be so large (i.e. the mass of the infalling system is so small relative to Perseus) as to not be relevant to the current discussion. However, it does suggest that alternative mechanisms such as cluster-to-cluster variations in the level of initial pre-heating may be an additional complication when interpreting the demographics of relaxed/unrelaxed and cool core/non-cool core clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Babul, McCarthy &amp; Poole 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">McCarthy et al. 2004</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225446 id=\"17225446\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7-3>7.3 Implications for cluster cosmology</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Massive galaxy clusters are one of a number of complementary probes of cosmological parameters. For example, many studies have used empirical determinations of cluster scaling relations to convert the observed X-ray luminosity and/or temperature functions into mass functions. The most massive clusters are rare objects, and thus the constraints on the high-mass end of the mass function inferred from such experiments enables constraints on a combination of \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub> and \u03c3<sub>8</sub>, in principle, to be achieved. Recent cluster-based estimates of \u03c3<sub>8</sub> have yielded discrepant results, with most estimates of \u03c3<sub>8</sub> falling in the range \u223c0.6\u20131 (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Eke et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nevalainen, Markevitch &amp; Forman 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borgani et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Pierpaoli, Scott &amp; White 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Reiprich &amp; B\u00f6hringer 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Viana et al. 2002</a>). The critical step in these experiments is the conversion from observable (i.e. X-ray luminosity or temperature) to mass. Our results suggest that care must be taken to incorporate sufficient scatter in the observable-mass relationship. The asymmetric scatter of the mass\u2013temperature relationship arising from structural segregation of clusters in this plane implies that such issues may be most acute when converting from cluster temperature to mass, especially if the cluster selection function is poorly characterized. Indeed, in a companion to this article, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2003)</a> showed that if the cluster selection functions are not well-matched between the sample of clusters used to measure the temperature function and the sample of clusters used to derive the temperature-to-mass conversion, then \u03c3<sub>8</sub> can be underestimated by \u223c20 per cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In a similar vein, we note that our results will probably impinge on cosmological results derived from SZE surveys (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Carlstrom, Holder &amp; Reese 2002</a> for a recent review). Again, the key issue is the precision to which the observable-mass relationship is known. The issues for SZE surveys may be aggravated because the goal of measuring the dark energy equation-of-state parameter <em>w</em>, relies at least in part on measuring the <em>evolution</em> of the cluster population between two redshifts straddling the epoch at which the dark energy is thought to take over as the dominant factor in the expansion of the Universe. This is in contrast to measuring a combination of \u03c3<sub>8</sub> and \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub> from studies of local clusters, i.e. just one redshift slice. Further detailed wide-field investigations of massive clusters at both low (<em>z</em> = 0.2) and higher (<em>z</em> \u2265 0.6) redshifts are therefore needed to quantify robustly the evolution of the dynamical maturity of clusters and the impact of that on cluster scaling relations. We suggest that, in the light of major imminent SZE cluster surveys, this is an urgent exercise.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17225449 id=\"17225449\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss8>8 Summary and Conclusions</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have undertaken a comprehensive study of the distribution of mass in 10 X-ray luminous (<em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 0.1\u20132.4 keV) galaxy clusters at <em>z</em> = 0.21 \u00b1 0.04. The cornerstone of our analysis is a suite of detailed gravitational lens models that describe the distribution of total mass in the cluster cores. These models are constrained by the gravitational lensing signal detected in high-resolution <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 imaging of the clusters, including numerous multiply imaged and weakly sheared background galaxies. Analysis of archival <em>Chandra</em> observations complements the lensing analysis and enables us to relate the total mass and structure of the clusters to the thermodynamics of the intracluster medium. We summarize the key results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><span class=\"label\">(i)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Five of the 10 clusters contain spectroscopically confirmed strong gravitational lensing, i.e. multiply imaged background galaxies. These five clusters comprise: A 68 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2002b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>), A 383 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2004</a>), A 963 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ellis, Allington-Smith &amp; Smail 1991</a>), A 2218 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Pell\u00f3 et al. 1992</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ellis et al. 2001</a>) and A 2219 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>).</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(ii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the remaining five clusters, two contain relatively unambiguous examples of strong lensing for which spectroscopic redshifts are not yet available (A 267 and A 1835). The other three clusters, A 209, A 773 and A 1763 do not contain any obviously multiply imaged galaxies; however, the optical richness and high mass (as derived from the weak-lensing signal) of A 773 suggest that this cluster may contain strong lensing that has yet to be uncovered.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(iii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on our search for strong lensing in these clusters down to a surface brightness limit of \u03bc<sub>702</sub>\u2243 25 mag arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>, we put a firm lower limit on the fraction of the clusters at <em>z</em> = 0.21 \u00b1 0.04 with <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> \u2265 8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4 keV) that have a central projected mass density in excess of the critical density required for gravitational lensing of 50 per cent. Including A 267 and A 1835 increases this limit to 70 per cent.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(iv)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the strong- and weak-lensing signals to constrain parametrized models of the cluster potential wells, and from these models compute maps of the total projected mass in the cluster cores. Spatial analysis of these maps reveals that four of the clusters form a relatively homogeneous subsample with very high central mass fractions (<em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> &gt; 0.95). The remaining six are strongly heterogeneous, with central mass fractions in the range 0.4 \u2264<em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> \u22640.9. The central mass fraction of <em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub>\u2243 0.95 that divides these two populations corresponds to a <em>K</em>-band central luminosity fraction of <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub>\u2243 0.5.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(v)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the six low central mass fraction clusters have an irregular, but not obviously bi-/tri-modal X-ray morphology. Four of the six are constrained by the current lensing data to have a bi-/tri-modal mass morphology (A 68, A 773, A 2218, A 2219). The other two (A 209 and A 1763) may be merging in the plane of the sky and thus any multimodality in their mass distributions is not well sampled by our WFPC2 pencil-beam survey of the cluster cores.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(vi)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Three of the four high central mass fraction clusters also have relaxed X-ray morphologies. The remaining cluster (A 267) has a disturbed X-ray morphology, with a \u223c90 kpc offset between its centres of X-ray emission and mass. The distribution of mass in this cluster may therefore be more complex than the single dark matter halo (plus cluster galaxies) that the current data are able to constrain.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(vii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combining all of the information available to us, we define \u2018relaxed\u2019 clusters to be those which appear relaxed in all available diagnostics, with the exception that we do not require a cool core. Quantitatively relaxed clusters therefore have a single cluster-scale DM halo in their lens model (<em>N</em><sub>DM</sub> = 1), a high central mass fraction (<em>M</em><sub>cen</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> \u2265 0.95) and central <em>K</em>-band luminosity fraction (<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,BCG</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em>,tot</sub> \u2265 0.5), no evidence for an offset between the X-ray emission and the centre of mass \u0394<em>r</em><sub>peak</sub> &lt; 4 kpc) and the X-ray morphology is either circular or mildly elliptical. The unrelaxed clusters do not meet at least one of these criteria.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(viii)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">Applying these criteria to the cluster sample, we conclude that seven of the 10 clusters are dynamically immature, i.e. unrelaxed (A 68, A 209, A 267, A 773, A 1763, A 2218, A 2219) and three are relaxed (A 383, A 963, A 1835); thus, formally 70 \u00b1 20 per cent of X-ray luminous cluster cores at <em>z</em> = 0.2 are unrelaxed.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(xi)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">We detect a factor of 3 more scatter in the mass\u2013temperature plane than predicted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evrard et al. (1996)</a>, implying that great care should be exercised when using such relations to convert cluster temperature functions to mass functions in pursuit of cosmological parameters. We also consider a number of key uncertainties that may artificially inflate our estimate of the scatter. This exercise suggests that approximately one-third of the scatter detected in this study may be due to issues related to the small field of view of our WFPC2 observations.</p></li><li><span class=\"label\">(x)</span><p class=\"chapter-para\">The scatter in the mass\u2013temperature plane is asymmetric, presenting evidence of structural segregation. The normalization of the mass\u2013temperature relation for unrelaxed (dynamically immature) clusters is 40 per cent hotter than for relaxed clusters at 2.5\u03c3 significance. This result is consistent with recent simulations of cluster\u2013cluster mergers (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ricker &amp; Sarazin 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Randall, Sarazin &amp; Ricker 2002</a>), implying that merger-induced temperature boosts may be the dominant factor behind the hotter normalization of unrelaxed systems.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, this study is the first of its kind, exploiting detailed strong-lensing constraints on the distribution of mass in X-ray luminous cluster cores, complemented by X-ray spectro-imaging with <em>Chandra</em>. The high frequency of dynamical immaturity, coupled with the structural segregation of the clusters in the mass\u2013temperature plane have profound implications for our understanding of how clusters form and evolve. Perhaps of greatest importance at this time is the implications of these results for using clusters to constrain the cosmological parameters, \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub>, \u03c3<sub>8</sub> and the dark energy equation-of-state parameter <em>w</em>. In a companion paper we demonstrate that inadequate knowledge of the cluster selection function can lead to 20 per cent systematic errors in cluster-based measurements of \u03c3<sub>8</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2003</a>). Turning to <em>w</em>, forthcoming Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich effect experiments designed to detect and measure the mass of clusters out to high redshifts, using mass\u2013SZE scaling relations may be compromised by unidentified and/or poorly calibrated astrophysical systematic uncertainties (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Majumdar &amp; Mohr 2003</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our future program will build on these results in three ways. First, we aim to overcome the principal uncertainties in the current work: small-number statistics and tiny field of view. Wide-field space-based imaging of a large statistically complete sample of clusters would be essential to achieve this goal. Secondly, a detailed comparison of selection effects and measurement techniques between theoretical and observational studies will enable a more detailed and rigorous comparison between observational and synthetic data sets. Finally, we are gathering <em>HST</em>/ACS imaging of an identically selected sample of clusters at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.55 drawn from the MACS sample (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry 2001</a>). We will combine these data with X-ray observations and compare the results to those found here. The \u223c3 Gyr difference in look-back time between <em>z</em> = 0.2 and 0.55 will enable us to search for evolutionary trends in the most massive clusters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225456 id=\"17225456\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss9>Acknowledgements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">GPS thanks Alastair Edge for much encouragement and assistance during this project. We also thank Steve Allen, Arif Babul, Michael Balogh, Sebastien Bardeau, John Blakeslee, Alain Blanchard, Richard Bower, Kevin Bundy, Warrick Couch, Sarah Bridle, Richard Ellis, Gus Evrard, Andy Fabian, Masataka Fukugita, Henk Hoekstra, Phillipe Marty, Ben Moore, Bob Nichol, Johan Richard, David Sand, Tommaso Treu and Mark Voit for a variety of helpful discussions, comments and assistance. GPS acknowledges financial support from PPARC. JPK acknowledges support from Caltech and CNRS. IRS acknowledges support from the Royal Society and the Leverhulme Trust. PM acknowledge support from the European commission contract number HRPN-CT-2000-00126 and by CXC grant GO2-3177X. HE acknowledges financial support under NASA grants NAG 5-6336 and NAG 5-8253. OC acknowledges support from the European Commission under contract no ER-BFM-BI-CT97-2471. We also acknowledge financial support from the UK\u2013French ALLIANCE collaboration programme no 00161XM.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17225459 id=\"17225459\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendices</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225460 id=\"17225460\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11>Appendix A: Gravitational Lens Modelling: Method</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This appendix describes relevant details of how the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> ray-tracing code is used to construct robust models of the distribution of mass in galaxy clusters using both strong- and weak-lensing constraints.</p>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=17225462 id=\"17225462\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11-1>A1 Mathematical overview</h5>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Consider a single source at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> that appears to an observer under the action of a gravitational lens at <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> as <em>N</em> distinct images at positions <strong><em>u</em></strong><sub><em>i</em></sub> (1 \u2264<em>i</em> \u2264<em>N</em>). We describe the source with \u03bd free parameters, \u03a0<sub><em>j</em></sub> (1 \u2264<em>j</em> \u2264\u03bd), for example: the position of the centre of the source, the ellipticity, the orientation and the surface brightness. We write the transformation equations in the following form:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma1\" content-id=\"ma1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq004.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq004.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=soHA9HS0yj8b~YoR9PvcpYPY1n2ViPwiu0z9DXT6-FcqUoD2vBiNDy0gbD9QDKv4RZiFqRqL5faB8QpTXGI3V~nqJHS65XL5vmI8t6Ck~hRrzvwVRfNPjURjJLbSM3DxWlHRCkZBDnchVb25gp8OFWbET9gV1Amn4mXojHI-VvLaP5rp4NVnfd-3xjd69PVQcBhGZA91QASsoz9gYPodZFhS0HVtcajUq8wnXbQzcUFx4PtSjO4g8Q5bJo0j-vLHOYmMu9TvnDmUmKL-l7nhvE1wBW~~ufGo~h-sFw09Z26kZT6ECLyeSR~KMQ1WwnNFHE0UsN4o4zr0lUOw4l6CfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq004.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A1)</span></div> where <em>f<sub>j</sub></em> are functions that depend on the parameters that describe the observed images and the gravitational potential of the lens. The source parameters, \u03a0<sup>S</sup><sub><em>j</em></sub>, and the lens potential, \u03d5(<strong><em>u</em></strong><sub><em>i</em></sub>), are the unknowns in these equations. We use the image parameters, \u03a0<sup>I</sup><sub><em>ji</em></sub> (I.E. the observables), to constrain both the source parameters and the lens potential. If we are able to recover \u03bd parameters for each image, then we have \u03bd(<em>N</em>\u2212 1) constraints on our lens model. Generalizing this to <em>n</em> sets of multiple images of sources at redshifts <em>z</em><sub>S<em>i</em></sub>, each multiple-image system being characterized by (\u03bd<sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>N<sub>i</sub></em>), then the total number of constraints <em>n</em><sub>c</sub> is given by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma2\" content-id=\"ma2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq005.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq005.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=jlZWChoGBUeKdtJEmkMx5jOrbVZWcn3yxhy4MPFsscm6g7rbCOXVNP6EuhssW4QKcSL8p7TbYZt8O4KnC41dV1iMRFY-YU7unRlE15Cx4~JdXIU1MmUzsLteJAc0oRGl2devAFr8ap3B6w6hF13itPN3HaNmVf-XuPCC9GFohYaTJtV1jL7Nl~vwkCvbYxsNLxnbP0GR6k6ja1yEkSMBSq3Leb4q3UJPZ2f3ZJRCXmwawhBOtrIHontmoy2urg0t1c~KCfgIAf5DZkkE8LKyrGTDil6bRBx4LUd2pvvkCT98-LhoKHKT~51iqIuRSoyURhcpv~For~D2XamKeINDlg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq005.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A2)</span></div> where \u03b5<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0 if <em>z</em><sub>S<em>i</em></sub> is known and \u03b5<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 1 if <em>z</em><sub>S<em>i</em></sub> is not known (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1993</a>). Strictly, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ma2\"></span><a href=\"#ma2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (A2)</a> only applies in the idealized case of all multiple-images being resolved, and none of the images being merging pairs. Clearly, higher resolution imaging will increase <em>n</em><sub>c</sub>.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We describe each observed gravitational image with the following parameters: \u03a0<sup>I</sup> = (<strong><em>u</em></strong><sup>I</sup>, <em>S</em><sup>I</sup>, \u03c4<sup><em>I</em></sup>), where <strong><em>u</em></strong><sup>I</sup> is the position of the image (defined as the centroid of a morphological feature in the arc that is identified as being multiply imaged), <em>S</em><sup>I</sup> is the observed flux and \u03c4<sup>I</sup> =\u03c4<sup>I</sup> e<sup>2i\u03b8I</sup> is the complex deformation of the image, describing its ellipticity (\u03c4) and orientation (\u03b8). We use these quantities and their counterparts in the source-plane to write down the transformation equations:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma3\" content-id=\"ma3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq006.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq006.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=dF81O7ezsxho3LoCgJRw8q4Abu7bGKS-piRItmSRDdtGivCDVq0h0gfCNIZnDC33nK8dg1Oa26kqRQ-CJBolm9fu8DQ7r4wwqkeCntdzv55IUxp6qvtc5V-bB8CSJqD0qwIt13VVs3G8lTdA-iws5Ahp2SOQ7Rhw0UCTB5gOTjCDdcHsU7LtbW0RKQPYMdAPYvztdEuCuKSTdjarj9T4XS7eQ1ZUb5OBPaXzrkykI8BThulpohzjfbAxI6E08oVU4IYWT2himW~gg08zwM4fO92S0WBF~R1X8ZEbDti6v0oP8pTcJ5Aty6M4hRkgDUJpjZnIWJorPPZMah-MaoMoVA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq006.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A3)</span></div> where the first equation is simply the lens equation, <em>J</em> is the Jacobian matrix of the lensing transformation, \u03b4= (1 +\u03c4<sup>2</sup>)<sup>1/2</sup>, <strong><em>g</em></strong> =<strong>\u03b3</strong>/(1 \u2212\u03ba), the subscript \u2018pot\u2019 denotes quantities applicable to a circular source (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1996</a> and references therein for a detailed derivation of the shape transformation equation), \u211c takes the real part of dot-product between <strong><em>g</em></strong><sup>I</sup> and <strong><em>g</em></strong>*<sub>pot</sub>, and <strong><em>g</em></strong>* is the complex conjugate of <strong><em>g</em></strong>.</div>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=17225465 id=\"17225465\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11-2>A2 Parametrization of the lens plane mass distribution</h5>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Each mass component is parametrized as a smoothly truncated pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (PIEMD; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kassiola &amp; Kovner 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>). This functional form is physically well motivated (it avoids the central singularity and infinite spatial extent of singular isothermal models) and can describe mass distributions of arbitrarily large ellipticities. Each PIEMD mass component is parametrized by its position (<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>, <em>y</em><sub>c</sub>), ellipticity (\u03b5), orientation (\u03b8), core radius (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub>), cut-off radius (<em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>) and central velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>o</sub>), and the projected mass density, \u03a3 is given by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma4\" content-id=\"ma4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq007.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq007.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=38kOdu0coWwxJKBQDOAOtdFPuGvBHKJjA9gCOhFXu5yB7AGMD4cu~hn3JvK50Ut7gTQZyykKOHdklgfaxhsKktLDvL4~B6mvdZK9erOJYXunuHeA9fG89FKSCoPFXBRLvGxy5s1FPrnUonYyz9PhWrWwnb0fr9WfUuPE17St3PpJ99H9U-Q4ggiv4JdsGJ5of3fHznRuflEs-lU1S8DPYhTARB4M0AFUFdmwuwTdsYrhcvkI5mpWqL-O8S~EqQbuCaesfKRbv4JNv0GIjQ2lS7RKD~~xGLP1YnANakyd2Zt6JWjsLvEabjzJiDBNjhlavh8cjsmF-vt4GJEojdn0pQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq007.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A4)</span></div> where \u03c1<sup>2</sup> =[(<em>x</em>\u2212<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>)/(1 +\u03b5)]<sup>2</sup>+[(<em>y</em>\u2212<em>y</em><sub>c</sub>)/(1 \u2212\u03b5)]<sup>2</sup> and the ellipticity of the lens is defined as \u03b5= (<em>a</em>\u2212<em>b</em>)/(<em>a</em>+<em>b</em>). The geometrical parameters (<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>, <em>y</em><sub>c</sub>, \u03b5, \u03b8) of each mass component are matched to the observed light distribution of the related cluster galaxy. The dynamical parameters (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>, \u03c3<sub>o</sub>) of the \u2018major mass components\u2019 (I.E. cluster-scale mass components and selected bright cluster galaxies, including each central galaxy) are kept as free parameters. To minimize the number of model parameters, the dynamical parameters of the remaining mass components are scaled with the luminosity of their associated galaxy following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brainerd, Blandford &amp; Smail (1996)</a>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma5\" content-id=\"ma5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq008.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq008.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=zubxhidJaLYU3CYXWsN6GuyA8U1YwNQD7OabpcleRs9IHVo6yNSgGIwr8-uQeVbhz-HMtZ9KQQR8nMwoN1Yhsi9txexH~psH0xPXEIvnDF9h~au~6pCvRRlkyxHzklWr5EaBaVDzDr0sx0jCIGiE0H1R5t~aqx-xRuCSvZYxrrocWT8ZC8PKNqM5rcJfZx8WFGeR4rLe8xe4dS3heaY9DogIpncKpVaGRiO3D2kn~uscpS0afWkhzxXiW8-KiwQrAYkbgU~zo9447iobjDty9IRWW~EIY3cbbHjlJ-wzLGbcr6v7rEidjArJAkqWuvqD3BQJgrpHqHstWwyRBXWnbw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq008.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A5)</span></div> We also scale the mass of individual galaxies with their luminosity, using<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma6\" content-id=\"ma6\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq009.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq009.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=JkWtxn73i5SK2kwFW6LFMu7rhWood2Q4E9rUzqNQKt4hX2Ng0thjlnCsDF1UjdXRnMe3eJu7AR7anLNi1NgXVhFdR1dhxVqnK-zdfiV30jKsi078Ac2gtiiOwylVrD1ZEU5sf3xCJboGGT~c3dPhGTW4p~VfeyANN9W6-vp2S2IUrM9L9Uwd9EKqzZM8-0tT3LVhQ3fnqYatxJVeK3a7vsakupwA1-7x9cmlMUUAUBpXnV6wJiBP5IJ0pKrC1SvAbZInEuiRwVB9-CJPi7pP-pTO3ZBHNOezlnsGux702GpkWB4vBBdj2xECE8EbSCGrMwwmcQy4A~i-1vm-qk35Qg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq009.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A6)</span></div> These scaling laws are physically well motivated and conserve the mass-to-light ratio of the galaxies in a manner analogous to the observed Faber\u2013Jackson and Tully\u2013Fisher scaling relations for spiral and elliptical galaxies, respectively.</div>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=17225467 id=\"17225467\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11-3>A3 Model optimization</h5>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We construct a \u03c7<sup>2</sup>-estimator to quantify how well each trial lens model fits the observational data:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma7\" content-id=\"ma7\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq010.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq010.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=3N68ITm37vqK-JEJ3O6~OtU7slRw2aQj6bQIlNWFrr38ymA2Mw1KCszXUy8M2eZSi2fsM5muzH-NcZOcpkXvjb~jDHdYvBtX7KXttWaAqSilJ63F-Mn2F70WGQnjmk-NNIXbGBKd~N7yCy4GUcEBGL8378y-h0SKAsGTLO7LLbEh9EbqvqqLs~BPE9JvtPnc8gRPfeDc5hJ3YE6RGdJCId9TpH5N4wFIcRvVwKV3eQE9ti8uGWhOXIiEBe6eNqiskJuvNjSmkE5cfNKOUK3ur3Ruktb4fHuzT9eMuI2pC8fUiVfJLBFnj5YVDw0oFkf5yeQIupf3n1rVwQ8NoK6xiw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq010.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A7)</span></div> The first three terms compare the source-plane properties computed for each observed image (<em>x</em><sup>S</sup><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>y</em><sup>S</sup><sub><em>i</em></sub>, \u03c4<sup>S</sup><sub><em>i</em></sub>, \u03b8<sup>S</sup><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>S</em><sup>S</sup><sub><em>i</em></sub>, as defined in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ma3\"></span><a href=\"#ma3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation A3</a>). We define \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>pos</sub>, \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>shape</sub> and \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>flux</sub> as follows:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma8\" content-id=\"ma8\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq011.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq011.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=fSMh7m6897XIpGvfeeASSJ4P0FaUEAuE94-g976ZMtJVi0dP758Xm-9VptxjZzSUtCzku2FKk~EJ6I2nohSnWYLzQzeV62zKJcriXihMInfb~aydyM9c0P-Yp4I0LZw8Z2eaeV5Aa8nkSO8~7mipF-7R-Hx~CTNpOdarKkYpj61VbD2cMcuB2XHWJRZscxWGC3EtqxThpEXnY6nXG90jo413ULEvzxiXS6Yait~816StS1Zsxfv0HEQ4ag4kLPIPwltxBCmPTWG5BXWfWKhCrbdTB0Q84A8OyhHSevIzubhS-BqWBz~zdmeAJ1zueRlIwbFJdm~YARWJXzkBeeOVpg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq011.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A8)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma9\" content-id=\"ma9\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq012.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq012.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=WCAJKJaO-YzUy28ls1EadIor-xVWQwto6jy4qUMUQA7SIvK9Iuy~tJ7RrHLQ9mafjApLMZAo1Do22hV8ppb~LTkMw~t5opxMSI9nD3T2cIG5xROUPrnX3qc53TdZXuDK6X9t1tfp-fyhPEx~v9wFkGcqoqvmNpl-1Oac8XLeklnDwyleLF5j4Jk8YiS32yfm5DVSqGEF4ScqR6lo9VJGjUtYq7hLcaped19bDvJbnDk2uJiSFqnoPGny9rdJ0dDOQDFtbQaGEo8~JoBn6CoNGALlYAE6oGHPLndbr4Boke0W0t2Ae~MXklZbthakoXC3XTIzgQyTIt3d9nCDEUqBpQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq012.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A9)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma10\" content-id=\"ma10\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq013.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq013.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=i5iZM71DDZ~NGEvZ8qD11jTzvLy8SMk7JqkpgFD440BEZh1uuadX7YCB5ibvIM6xgsFgNUnjWv5DlgwdiwpniDdbtJrQdRDkrPle1JqID-Y8aZP7TFTvc-D2-rlXjYbgQowRIeVmNMbhmuXXSQl0FolFhTvQp4vCPjfpjlYXv6XWejd-Z1SAkeQ5IH~6gHVRanAD84fIvk35MnS~JIFD5f4MzkhiwJOiSjCRzVM0J~jyDp3z0nZRar4Jo2Jf86cKeGMm5kPOZc7RZib~5LRZY6vI-Xvk8Fde2Lv9mdKXvUzKYJpFEBbCO82S5UVvxqGhFyGTj4LqxcOiGX9U5QYP3w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq013.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A10)</span></div> where \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>pos</sub>, \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>shape</sub> and \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>flux</sub> are the accuracies with which we can measure the position, shape and flux of galaxies in our <em>HST</em> data.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The fourth term in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ma7\"></span><a href=\"#ma7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (A7)</a> compares how well the symmetry breaks in the observed gravitational images (I.E. locations of critical lines) are reproduced by the lens model. We define (<em>x</em><sup>obs</sup><sub>ct</sub>, <em>y</em><sup>obs</sup><sub>ct</sub>) and (<em>x</em><sup>mod</sup><sub>ct</sub>, <em>y</em><sup>mod</sup><sub>ct</sub>) as the observed and model critical line positions, respectively, and construct \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>crit</sub>, where \u0394<em>x</em><sub>crit</sub> and \u0394<em>y</em><sub>crit</sub> are the uncertainties in the position of the symmetry break.<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma11\" content-id=\"ma11\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq014.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq014.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=AI8eekdSlaQ~6BKYJJoBhnvRN8fUX7C3zzo0361tmwh7cIpMGK-Jnq3rAsQqNMZwtURmeZF37v8ZmU~g~Npl20EVCvmvqZN3wgKKtBU79n1DYyjNDv~r7lYQq4iFRNsDK~skgeNBUNtS9H2jEwq7qYLVAU-Sl0wXzxWODB2O7fGB4qYnKv~i8IDB-mrrINzOOjJGCZHrQuhLfQ52dAIOMK2mfVNkvXcby~6Q-AeLmtchFSaZhDqEu5Af8gBs6V4N5MnYC36lg9eVymn61WxdtWp8sIcS87YVtXlHB5g28~evQ1sE0x0L9umKCwnB6M-J3u56IQc4Jte2zdOGyUd13Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq014.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A11)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Finally, we construct \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>weak</sub> in a similar manner to \u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>shape</sub>; the differences being that we sum over the <em>F</em> faint galaxy images detected in the cluster field, \u03c3<sub>weak</sub> is the width of the distribution of galaxy shapes from surveys of field galaxies (E.G. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels 1998</a>) and we compare the image-plane galaxy shapes with that induced by the trial mass distribution at the faint galaxy image on a circular source.<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"ma12\" content-id=\"ma12\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"359-2-417-eq015.jpeg\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-eq015.jpeg?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=5JJ7wQYAUjlBAWnjAiONfCfED7XiKB~ZkMv6KgXz64eiBz8nPA7wgdNLRimX~DkNMIp69D-fgNFXXxhtiaH55uhd-lqOKIPxm03GNkKR2oeEDKMP7E4AuB-PzYsUlTAIVJmFiGpz8Y1gKaigx-htYCLHw~9TyZRJGOCLBAyOl-geqw-p28F6fn5k4QBDOfQLVCOs0vGjlSCdI5DkoXzeH-8n1SDmcgMKr~HR4E~3dsluqcZZ2rvvSwpWBkyMdFQF2nVCwlyyaFloujj7XsN~8lFEdDNxnsxonNRdhrgEZ1ijUeAyYXrGZB0VTBO9-2lmAHQelq4dKgWlfyqIcL4FRg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-eq015.jpeg\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">(A12)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The \u03c7<sup>2</sup> estimator is minimized by varying the model parameters to obtain an acceptable (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u223c 1) fit to the observational constraints. This is an iterative process, which we begin by restricting our attention to the least ambiguous model constraints (I.E. the confirmed multiple-image systems) and the relevant free parameters. For example, in a typical cluster lens there will be one spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image system and a few other candidate multiples. The model-fitting process therefore begins with using the spectroscopic multiple to constrain the dynamical parameters of the main cluster-scale mass component.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225472 id=\"17225472\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss12>383 Appendix B: Interpretation of the Giant Tangential and Radial Arcs in A</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this appendix we update the multiple-image interpretation of the giant tangential and radial arcs in A 383. This system was originally discussed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2001)</a>, who obtained a redshift of <em>z</em> = 1.01 for the brightest component of the tangential arc (green ellipse, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. B1</a>; B0a, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a>). Smith et al. interpreted the tangential and radial arcs as consisting of several multiply imaged galaxies at 1.01 \u2264<em>z</em> \u2264 1.2, based on the arc geometry and photometry.</p>                        <a id=\"17225474\" scrollto-destination=\"17225474\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig011.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=MpH5qE6I4Lt5CAiK81JVBFNYeugyUQnvG31lURtKq4VL9WoKT~IMRER7OBaT7bT62qrn8cyxxykyi-InU8Qa-QflfX11rWE59ODY8t3aeZ~aQoyyTXOBLmxhLM3E8bkDR~IJtph0tZGufR7G8VEHuFqEZgWzFlOV1e9aZXoQ8M97sA~c7eN5ZLSUANBdeXgUSrpMu1IYpVr48NheHW2mQtHMlTH4SNtS~L86~XbbtjBos3BcSgzLapkssfoj6DLP1sKrHszsuWSnve5oCGAA8IXNfA0DQfiru~27OgjJqNUv6uWrky6KtualHzK~6ezmGxIwd3DikCkO~JFFReHXBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The giant tangential and radial arcs in A 383, based on Sand et al.'s (2004) digital subtraction of the BCG from the WFPC2 frame. Left: the central 40 \u00d7 40 arcsec2, showing the tangential and radial critical lines as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The white filled ellipses and labels mark the revised multiple-image interpretation, as described in the text. Right: zoom into the central 12 \u00d7 12 arcsec2; the tangential and radial caustics are shown as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The source-plane positions of the portions of the galaxy marked as A, B and C in the left-hand panel are marked, as described in more detail in the text. Both panels are oriented with north up and east to the left. The thin arc-like features in the left-hand panel are residuals from the subtraction of the BCG and other bright cluster galaxies. The bright roughly circular feature, just below the centre in each panel is a compact object that is not removed from the frame when subtracting a smooth model of the BCG. See Sand et al. (2004) for more details on the galaxy subtraction process and the residuals.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225474/359-2-417-fig011.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225474\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig011.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=OofHdhphanFEHuEQKgwNkJzMUMxZxnHq~Qi9eLBa0XR3RLaNckeSrcL4wbjiB6wIvlZdo44OPQ4tMFxC5VtHt9bFIDvYy9KKCwDUNaD7mojR6gtuLoMi-N-gJ2nhh3v3wHVeDLKYwD7HwGxNduzeluMJuq772heKyvCIExQPyGWAHClrioyuYpEf40BegzVsndFevssJc5b8oAhg2IvJXxCdkRFY~8RM3YZJ88qOpN4VDgqllaspxvz2f2BNDczbyJnyQjeOzGe-3aXjjXGhCAdeRbDXzKZchz8ZHKqfRtlzvULWov5Jvf4l1CoaB8LJuZ5PHHPwA7beAlxIF8ehMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225474&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The giant tangential and radial arcs in A 383, based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al.'s (2004)</a> digital subtraction of the BCG from the WFPC2 frame. Left: the central 40 \u00d7 40 arcsec<sup>2</sup>, showing the tangential and radial critical lines as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The white filled ellipses and labels mark the revised multiple-image interpretation, as described in the text. Right: zoom into the central 12 \u00d7 12 arcsec<sup>2</sup>; the tangential and radial caustics are shown as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The source-plane positions of the portions of the galaxy marked as A, B and C in the left-hand panel are marked, as described in more detail in the text. Both panels are oriented with north up and east to the left. The thin arc-like features in the left-hand panel are residuals from the subtraction of the BCG and other bright cluster galaxies. The bright roughly circular feature, just below the centre in each panel is a compact object that is not removed from the frame when subtracting a smooth model of the BCG. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. (2004)</a> for more details on the galaxy subtraction process and the residuals.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/m_359-2-417-fig011.gif?Expires=1639265910&amp;Signature=MpH5qE6I4Lt5CAiK81JVBFNYeugyUQnvG31lURtKq4VL9WoKT~IMRER7OBaT7bT62qrn8cyxxykyi-InU8Qa-QflfX11rWE59ODY8t3aeZ~aQoyyTXOBLmxhLM3E8bkDR~IJtph0tZGufR7G8VEHuFqEZgWzFlOV1e9aZXoQ8M97sA~c7eN5ZLSUANBdeXgUSrpMu1IYpVr48NheHW2mQtHMlTH4SNtS~L86~XbbtjBos3BcSgzLapkssfoj6DLP1sKrHszsuWSnve5oCGAA8IXNfA0DQfiru~27OgjJqNUv6uWrky6KtualHzK~6ezmGxIwd3DikCkO~JFFReHXBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The giant tangential and radial arcs in A 383, based on Sand et al.'s (2004) digital subtraction of the BCG from the WFPC2 frame. Left: the central 40 \u00d7 40 arcsec2, showing the tangential and radial critical lines as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The white filled ellipses and labels mark the revised multiple-image interpretation, as described in the text. Right: zoom into the central 12 \u00d7 12 arcsec2; the tangential and radial caustics are shown as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The source-plane positions of the portions of the galaxy marked as A, B and C in the left-hand panel are marked, as described in more detail in the text. Both panels are oriented with north up and east to the left. The thin arc-like features in the left-hand panel are residuals from the subtraction of the BCG and other bright cluster galaxies. The bright roughly circular feature, just below the centre in each panel is a compact object that is not removed from the frame when subtracting a smooth model of the BCG. See Sand et al. (2004) for more details on the galaxy subtraction process and the residuals.\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17225474/359-2-417-fig011.gif\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17225474\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/359/2/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08911.x/2/359-2-417-fig011.gif?Expires=1639265910&Signature=OofHdhphanFEHuEQKgwNkJzMUMxZxnHq~Qi9eLBa0XR3RLaNckeSrcL4wbjiB6wIvlZdo44OPQ4tMFxC5VtHt9bFIDvYy9KKCwDUNaD7mojR6gtuLoMi-N-gJ2nhh3v3wHVeDLKYwD7HwGxNduzeluMJuq772heKyvCIExQPyGWAHClrioyuYpEf40BegzVsndFevssJc5b8oAhg2IvJXxCdkRFY~8RM3YZJ88qOpN4VDgqllaspxvz2f2BNDczbyJnyQjeOzGe-3aXjjXGhCAdeRbDXzKZchz8ZHKqfRtlzvULWov5Jvf4l1CoaB8LJuZ5PHHPwA7beAlxIF8ehMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17225474&ar=986735&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"359-2-417-fig011.gif\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The giant tangential and radial arcs in A 383, based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al.'s (2004)</a> digital subtraction of the BCG from the WFPC2 frame. Left: the central 40 \u00d7 40 arcsec<sup>2</sup>, showing the tangential and radial critical lines as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The white filled ellipses and labels mark the revised multiple-image interpretation, as described in the text. Right: zoom into the central 12 \u00d7 12 arcsec<sup>2</sup>; the tangential and radial caustics are shown as blue solid and dashed curves, respectively. The source-plane positions of the portions of the galaxy marked as A, B and C in the left-hand panel are marked, as described in more detail in the text. Both panels are oriented with north up and east to the left. The thin arc-like features in the left-hand panel are residuals from the subtraction of the BCG and other bright cluster galaxies. The bright roughly circular feature, just below the centre in each panel is a compact object that is not removed from the frame when subtracting a smooth model of the BCG. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. (2004)</a> for more details on the galaxy subtraction process and the residuals.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">More recently <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. (2004)</a> obtained the redshift of both the radial arc and the image pair B1a/b (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a>; white ellipses, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. B1</a>), confirming that both lie at <em>z</em> = 1.01. We have updated Smith et al.'s lens model to include this new constraint. The main implication of Sand et al.'s result is that it now seems most likely that the entire radial and tangential arc system arises from a galaxy (or galaxies) at a single source-plane redshift of <em>z</em> = 1.01, and not several systems at 1.01 \u2264<em>z</em> \u2264 1.2 as suggested by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2001)</a>. However, one of the attractions of Smith et al.'s interpretation was that it naturally explained why the bright component, B0a, appears only once in the giant tangential arc. Any new interpretation of the data must still be able to explain this. Part of the solution lies in the interpretation of the radial arc, especially the innermost regions which are heavily obscured by the bright central galaxy in this cluster. Smith et al. suggested that the inner portion of the radial arc comprises two images of the same galaxy which appears as B0a in the tangential arc. We attempt to validate this idea using Sand et al.'s version of the WFPC2 frame from which the BCG has been digitally subtracted. The surface brightness of the radial arc is inconsistent (too low) with Smith et al.'s interpretation on projected scales of \u22651 arcsec. On smaller scales the residuals from Sand et al.'s BCG subtraction dominate. In summary, it appears likely that B0a is not a counter image of the radial arc, and is therefore singly imaged.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the new multiple-image interpretation of the arcs in A 383 which is consistent with the new data discussed above in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. B1</a>. In the following explanation, we assume for simplicity that the entire arc system comprises just one galaxy in the source plane. In the left-hand panel, the white filled ellipses labelled \u2018A\u2019 show three tangential images of one portion of the galaxy at <em>z</em> = 1.01; the ellipse labelled \u2018B\u2019 shows the singly imaged portion, which appears to have a central bulge-like morphology; the ellipses marked \u2018C\u2019 show three images of a third portion of the galaxy \u2013 two of them form the radial arc and the counter image appears as part of the tangential arc. In the source plane this can be understood in terms of a galaxy positioned as shown in the right-hand panel with respect to the tangential and radial caustics. The \u2018A\u2019 portion of the galaxy lies just inside the tangential caustic and the \u2018C\u2019 portion lies just inside the radial caustic. The \u2018B\u2019 portion lies just outside of both the tangential and radial caustics, and is therefore singly imaged.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17225477 id=\"17225477\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss13>Appendix C: Astrometric Details of Gravitational Arcs Identified in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a></h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The purpose of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblc1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblc1\" data-open=\"tblc1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table C1</a> is to assist in the identification of candidate gravitational arcs identified in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>. The intention is that this information is used in conjunction with the WFPC2 data itself, and not as a substitute for it, when constructing detailed lens models of the clusters. For example, the position of the Northern arc in A 962 (H0) is given at the position of the brightest feature in the arc, and not as the positions of the three images that are likely merging to form the arc. In general, the position of each arc is defined as the centroid of the most prominent morphological feature in the F702W <em>HST</em> imaging, and is stated as an offset from the central galaxy in each cluster. The positions of the central galaxies are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17225479\" scrollto-destination=\"17225479\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"tblc1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div
